  2. Additional slots appear as you connect more PDBs.

docs.title: Batch Multiple PDBs
docs.text:
• Combine single or batched PDB dictionaries into one batch.
  • Automatically checks for unique IDs to prevent conflicts.
  • Supports up to 30 PDB inputs.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb_1 PDB to add to batch (single or batch). pdb_2 appears after connecting pdb_1. PDB {"1abc": "...PDB..."}

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb_2+ Additional PDBs to add to batch. Each slot appears after the previous is set. PDB {"2def": "...PDB..."}

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example structure.pdb Batch of PDBs as a dict {pdb_id: pdb_content}. PDB {"1abc": "...", "2def": "..."}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure all PDB IDs are unique to avoid errors.
  • Use upstream nodes that assign or allow setting PDB IDs.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Use Batch PDB to merge results before batch processing or evaluation.
  • Connect only the PDBs you need for the batch to avoid unnecessary data.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Duplicate PDB IDs: The node will raise an error if any PDB IDs are repeated. Ensure all input PDBs have unique IDs.
  • Missing Inputs: At least one PDB input (pdb_1) is required.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: FASTA Combiner
docs.text: Combine multiple FASTA sequences into a single FASTA input for downstream processing.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect up to five FASTA inputs to the node.
  2. Enable the separator option to add comments between combined sequences (optional).
  3. Use the output as a single FASTA input for other nodes.

docs.title: 1. Add the Node
docs.text:
1. Insert the FASTA Combiner node into your workflow.
  2. Connect FASTA outputs from upstream nodes to the available inputs.

docs.title: 2. Configure Options
docs.text:
1. Optionally enable the separator to add comments between combined FASTA blocks.
  2. Leave unused FASTA inputs empty if combining fewer than five sequences.

docs.title: Combine Multiple FASTA Sequences
docs.text:
• Merge up to five FASTA inputs into a single FASTA string.
  • Optionally insert separator comments for clarity.
  • Use the combined output as input for downstream sequence analysis or modeling nodes.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text:
Field Description Type Example fasta_1 First FASTA sequence(s) FASTA >A
MKT... fasta_2 Second FASTA sequence(s) FASTA >B
GYL... fasta_3 Third FASTA sequence(s) FASTA >C
LIA... fasta_4 Fourth FASTA sequence(s) FASTA >D
NSS... fasta_5 Fifth FASTA sequence(s) FASTA >E
GTA... separator Add separator comments between different inputs BOOL true

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example combined_fasta Combined FASTA string from inputs FASTA >A\nMKT...

docs.title: Input Management
docs.text:
• Only connect FASTA inputs you need; leave others empty.
  • Use the separator option to clarify boundaries between combined sequences, especially when merging unrelated data.

docs.title: Downstream Compatibility
docs.text:
• Ensure the combined FASTA is compatible with downstream nodes expecting a single FASTA input.
  • Validate the output if combining sequences from different sources to avoid ID conflicts.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No output generated: Ensure at least one FASTA input is provided.
  • Unexpected sequence order: Inputs are combined in order (fasta_1 to fasta_5); check connections.
  • Downstream errors: Confirm the combined FASTA format matches requirements of subsequent nodes.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Load PDB
docs.text: Loads PDB content from a string and assigns a unique ID for use in downstream workflows. The output is a dictionary with the PDB ID as the key and the PDB string as the value.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Enter or paste your PDB string.
  2. Specify a unique PDB ID (match with FASTA if needed).
  3. Connect the output to downstream nodes.

docs.title: 1. Prepare PDB Input
docs.text:
1. Obtain or generate your PDB string.
  2. Ensure you have a unique identifier for this PDB.

docs.title: 2. Node Configuration
docs.text:
1. Input the PDB string in the provided field.
  2. Set the PDB ID (default is "pdb").
  3. Connect the output to other nodes as required.

docs.title: Single PDB Loading
docs.text:
• Load a single PDB structure for use in a workflow.
  • Assign a unique ID to ensure compatibility with batch and sequence nodes.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb_string PDB string to upload. STRING ATOM ... pdb_id ID assigned to this PDB. Should be unique if using multiple PDBs. STRING 1abc

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example structure.pdb Dictionary with pdb_id as key and pdb_string as value. {"1abc": "ATOM ..."}

docs.title: Unique Identification
docs.text:
• Always assign a unique PDB ID, especially when using multiple PDBs in a workflow.
  • Match the PDB ID with the corresponding FASTA sequence ID if both are used.

docs.title: Data Integrity
docs.text:
• Validate your PDB string for formatting errors before uploading.
  • Use descriptive IDs to simplify workflow management.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Duplicate PDB IDs: Ensure each PDB has a unique ID to avoid downstream errors.
  • Invalid PDB Format: Check that the PDB string is correctly formatted and complete.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: PDB To Fasta
docs.text: Extracts FASTA-formatted amino acid sequences from the provided PDB record, supporting extraction for specific chains or all chains in the structure.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect a PDB input (single or batch) to the node.
  2. Specify chain IDs as a comma-separated string (e.g., A,B), or leave empty to extract all chains.
  3. Run the node to obtain FASTA sequences for each chain.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input
docs.text:
1. Ensure your PDB input is a valid dictionary {pdb_id: pdb_content}.
  2. Identify the chain(s) you wish to extract (e.g., A, B, or leave empty for all).

docs.title: 2. Node Configuration
docs.text:
1. Set the chains field to the desired chain IDs (comma-separated), or leave empty for all chains.
  2. Connect the node in your workflow.

docs.title: Extracting FASTA from a Single Chain
docs.text:
• Provide a PDB with a single chain and specify its ID in chains (e.g., A).
  • The output will be a FASTA record for that chain.

docs.title: Extracting FASTA from Multiple Chains
docs.text:
• Provide a PDB with multiple chains and specify multiple IDs (e.g., A,B).
  • The output will include a FASTA record for each specified chain.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Protein to extract FASTA from. PDB {"1abc": "...PDB content..."} chains Comma-separated chain IDs, or empty for all. STRING A,B

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example seqs.fasta FASTA records (sequence per chain) extracted from PDB. >1abc_chain_A\nMKT...

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure PDB input is properly formatted and contains valid chain IDs.
  • Use unique PDB IDs to avoid confusion in batch processing.

docs.title: Chain Selection
docs.text:
• Specify only the chains you need to minimize unnecessary output.
  • Leave chains empty to extract all available chains if unsure.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No valid protein sequences found in the PDB: Ensure the PDB contains standard amino acid residues and correct chain IDs.
  • Empty output: Check that the specified chains exist in the input PDB.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• PDB Format Guide
  • FASTA Format Reference
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: PDB Visualization
docs.text: Generates an HTML string for interactive protein structure visualization from a PDB input. Designed for previewing single PDB records; if a batch is provided, only the first (alphabetically) is visualized.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect a node outputting a PDB to the PDB Visualization node.
  2. Run the workflow.
  3. Use the Output node to preview the protein structure interactively.

docs.title: 1. Add the Node
docs.text:
1. Insert the PDB Visualization node into your workflow.
  2. Connect a PDB output from any compatible node.

docs.title: 2. Preview the Structure
docs.text:
1. Connect the output of this node to an Output node.
  2. Run the workflow to view the protein in an embedded viewer.

docs.title: Visualizing a Protein Structure
docs.text:
• Use for quick inspection of a single PDB structure.
  • If a batch is provided, only the first record is shown.
  • Suitable for integration in protein design and analysis pipelines.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb PDB to visualize. If a batch, only the first is shown. PDB { "1abc": "...PDB content..." }

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example html HTML string for protein preview. <!DOCTYPE html>...

docs.title: Visualization
docs.text:
• Use for single-structure visualization; batch support is not available.
  • Connect directly to an Output node for immediate preview.

docs.title: Data Integrity
docs.text:
• Ensure the PDB input is valid and contains at least one record.
  • For batch PDBs, verify the desired structure is first alphabetically if previewing a specific one.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No structure displayed: Ensure the input PDB is valid and not empty.
  • Batch input not fully visualized: Only the first PDB in a batch is shown; split batches if needed.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Mol* Viewer Documentation
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Save To Bucket
docs.text: Uploads all connected inputs to a specified folder path in a GCP bucket, applying a merge strategy for results from multiple runs. Returns a temporary download link for a zip containing the current state of the folder.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect outputs from any nodes you wish to save.
  2. Specify a unique folder_path for your experiment in the bucket.
  3. Run the node to upload and merge results.
  4. Connect the output URL to an Output node to download the zip snapshot.

docs.title: 1. Connect Inputs
docs.text:
1. Attach outputs from any nodes (PDBs, FASTAs, CSVs, etc.) to the results inputs.
  2. Add more results by connecting to additional results_i slots as needed.

docs.title: 2. Configure Folder Path
docs.text:
1. Set folder_path to a meaningful, unique path (e.g., project1/experimentA).
  2. Avoid generic names like test to prevent accidental data merging.

docs.title: 3. Run and Download
docs.text:
1. Execute the workflow.
  2. Use the output URL to download the merged results as a zip file.

docs.title: Uploading Results to GCP Bucket
docs.text:
• Save any combination of node outputs (PDB, FASTA, CSV, JSON, etc.).
  • Specify a bucket folder path to organize results.
  • Automatically merges results from multiple runs using unique execution IDs.
  • Download a zip snapshot of the current folder state.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example results_i Output from any node to save (add more by connecting to results_2, etc.) ANY PDB, FASTA, CSV, JSON folder_path Path to the output folder in GCP bucket. Supports nested paths. STRING project1/experimentA

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example url Temporary download link for a zip snapshot of the current folder state in the bucket. https://storage.googleapis.com/.../file.zip

docs.title: Folder Organization
docs.text:
• Use descriptive, unique folder paths to avoid accidental data merging.
  • Group related experiments under a common parent folder for easier management.

docs.title: Data Management
docs.text:
• Download the zip after each run to keep local backups.
  • Regularly review bucket contents to avoid clutter and confusion.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty folder_path error: Ensure folder_path is not empty or generic. Use a unique, descriptive path.
  • Unexpected data merging: Results from different runs with the same folder_path are merged. Use unique paths for separate experiments.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• GCP Storage Documentation
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Save To Zip
docs.text: Saves all connected node outputs into a downloadable zip folder, preserving folder and file structure based on node metadata. Enables selective export of results (PDBs, FASTAs, CSVs, etc.) for local download.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect outputs from any nodes you wish to save.
  2. Add additional results as needed (slots appear dynamically).
  3. Connect the Save To Zip node output to the Output node.
  4. Download the generated zip file via the provided URL.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Insert the Save To Zip node into your workflow.
  2. Connect outputs from other nodes (e.g., PDB, FASTA, CSV).

docs.title: 2. Configure and Run
docs.text:
1. Add more results by connecting to new slots as they appear.
  2. Run the workflow and download the zip from the Output node.

docs.title: Exporting Results
docs.text:
• Save any combination of node outputs (PDBs, FASTAs, CSVs, JSON, etc.)
  • Folder and file names are auto-generated based on node metadata
  • Download a single zip containing all selected results

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example results_1 Output from any node to save (additional slots appear as needed) ANY PDB, FASTA, CSV

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example url URL to download the created zip file locally STRING /output/abc/abc.zip

docs.title: Organizing Exports
docs.text:
• Connect only the outputs you need to save
  • Use meaningful node names for easier folder navigation in the zip

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Always connect the Save To Zip output to an Output node for easy download
  • Use multiple Save To Zip nodes if you want to export different result sets

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No zip file generated: Ensure at least one result is connected.
  • Duplicate folder names: Multiple instances of the same node will be auto-suffixed (e.g., node, node_2).
  • Missing expected files: Check that all desired outputs are connected to the node.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Evaluate Diversity
docs.text: Runs diversity evaluation pipeline on the provided batch of proteins. Clusters structures based on TM-score and outputs a CSV table with cluster indices for each input.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect a batch of PDB structures to the node.
  2. Set the maximum TM-score threshold for clustering (e.g., 0.6).
  3. Specify the number of processes for parallel evaluation (default: 8).
  4. Run the node to obtain a CSV with cluster assignments.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Structures
docs.text:
1. Generate or collect a batch of PDB structures to evaluate.
  2. Ensure each structure has a unique identifier.

docs.title: 2. Configure Diversity Evaluation
docs.text:
1. Set max_ctm_threshold to control cluster separation (lower = stricter clustering).
  2. Adjust num_processes for available compute resources.

docs.title: Batch Diversity Assessment
docs.text:
• Cluster a set of generated or designed proteins to assess structural diversity.
  • Identify representative structures from each cluster for downstream analysis.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Structures to evaluate. PDB {"design_1": "...", "design_2": "..."} max_ctm_threshold Maximum TM score threshold between clusters. FLOAT 0.6 num_processes Number of processes for parallel evaluation. INT 8

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example score.csv Scores of the pdbs (cluster indices). CSV file with cluster assignments

docs.title: Diversity Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Use a lower max_ctm_threshold for stricter clustering (more clusters, higher diversity sensitivity).
  • Increase num_processes to speed up evaluation on large batches if hardware allows.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Use after protein generation to select diverse candidates for further analysis.
  • Combine with functional evaluation nodes for comprehensive assessment.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• All structures assigned to one cluster: Try lowering max_ctm_threshold to increase sensitivity.
  • Node runs slowly on large batches: Increase num_processes if possible, or reduce batch size.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Evaluate Prot Param
docs.text: Runs protein parameters evaluation on the provided batch of proteins, calculating various sequence and structure properties at specified pH values.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect a PDB batch to the node's input.
  2. Specify a comma-separated list of pH values (e.g., 7,5.5,8).
  3. Run the node to obtain a CSV table of protein parameters.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Generate or load a batch of protein structures in PDB format.
  2. Ensure each PDB has a unique identifier.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Set the pH_list field to the desired pH values (comma-separated, e.g., 7,5.5,8).
  2. Connect the PDB input.

docs.title: 3. Run Evaluation
docs.text:
1. Execute the node to compute parameters for each structure at each specified pH.
  2. Download or inspect the resulting CSV output.

docs.title: Batch Protein Parameter Evaluation
docs.text:
• Evaluate isoelectric point, charge, and other sequence/structure properties for multiple proteins at different pH values.
  • Use in workflows to compare designed proteins or validate generated structures.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Structures to evaluate. PDB {"design_0": "...PDB..."} pH_list Comma-separated list of float pHs to calculate protein charge. STRING 7,5.5,8

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example score.csv Scores of the foldings (various protein/sequence params) CSV

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use unique IDs for each PDB to avoid confusion in batch outputs.
  • Provide realistic pH values relevant to your experimental or biological context.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Combine with diversity or functional evaluation nodes for comprehensive protein assessment.
  • Use in automated pipelines to benchmark multiple designs.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty or malformed PDB input: Ensure all PDBs are valid and properly formatted.
  • Incorrect pH format: Use comma-separated floats (e.g., 7,5.5), not lists or other delimiters.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Evaluate Unconditional Initial Guess
docs.text: Runs unconditional evaluation on outputs from the Alphafold Initial Guess node. Merges initial guess scores with unconditional evaluation scores and returns the resulting scores table.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect generated proteins (PDB) and foldings (PDB) from previous nodes.
  2. Provide the initial guess score table (STRING) from Alphafold Initial Guess.
  3. Run the node to obtain the best folding and merged scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Generate proteins using a diffusion or design node.
  2. Predict foldings using the Alphafold Initial Guess node.
  3. Collect the score table output from Alphafold Initial Guess.

docs.title: 2. Connect and Run
docs.text:
1. Connect the generated PDB, folding PDB, and initial guess score STRING to this node.
  2. Execute the node to receive evaluation results.

docs.title: Evaluate Initial Guess
docs.text:
• Assess the quality of generated proteins using foldings and initial guess scores.
  • Use in workflows requiring evaluation of Alphafold Initial Guess outputs.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example generation_pdb Generated proteins to evaluate PDB {"id": "..."} folding_pdb Foldings to evaluate proteins against PDB {"id": "..."} initial_guess_score Score table from initial guess prediction (from Alphafold node) STRING "score.sc"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example best_folding.pdb Best of the predicted foldings {"id": "..."} score.csv Scores of the foldings (csv table) "score.csv"

docs.title: Input Consistency
docs.text:
• Ensure IDs in generation and folding PDBs match for correct evaluation.
  • Use the exact score output from Alphafold Initial Guess for accurate merging.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Place this node after Alphafold Initial Guess in evaluation pipelines.
  • Use the output scores for downstream analysis or selection.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Mismatched IDs: Ensure input PDBs and score tables use consistent IDs.
  • Missing score table: Always connect the score output from Alphafold Initial Guess.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Evaluate Unconditional
docs.text: Runs unconditional evaluation pipeline on the outputs of Alphafold or Colabfold models. Selects a folding that is most similar to the generation and returns a scores table.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect generated proteins (PDB) to generation_pdb input.
  2. Connect foldings (PDB) to folding_pdb input.
  3. Run the node to obtain the best folding and evaluation scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Generate proteins using a diffusion or design node.
  2. Obtain foldings from Alphafold or Colabfold nodes.

docs.title: 2. Connect and Run
docs.text:
1. Connect the generated proteins to generation_pdb.
  2. Connect the foldings to folding_pdb.
  3. Execute the node to receive evaluation results.

docs.title: Unconditional Evaluation
docs.text:
• Compare generated proteins to predicted foldings.
  • Select the best matching folding for each design.
  • Output a CSV table with evaluation metrics (pst, rmsd, pae, plddt).

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example generation_pdb Generated proteins to evaluate. PDB {"design_0": "...PDB..."} folding_pdb Foldings to evaluate proteins against. PDB {"design_0_ranked_0": "...PDB..."}

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example best_folding.pdb Best of the predicted foldings. {"design_0": "...PDB..."} score.csv Scores of the foldings (pst, rmsd, pae, plddt). "design_0,0.95,1.2,10.5,85.0"

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure that generation_pdb and folding_pdb have matching or corresponding IDs for accurate evaluation.
  • Use outputs from supported generation and folding nodes for compatibility.

docs.title: Efficient Evaluation
docs.text: • For large batches, consider running in TEST mode to limit evaluation to the first structure for faster feedback.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Mismatched IDs: Ensure that the IDs in generation_pdb and folding_pdb correspond to the same designs.
  • Empty Outputs: Check that both inputs contain valid PDB data.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Haddock
docs.text: Predicts docking of candidate proteins against a target protein using the HADDOCK protocol. Returns the best docking pose, all docked models, and a table of docking scores.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare candidate and target PDB structures using Load PDB node.
  2. (Optional) Adjust docking configuration parameters as needed.
  3. Connect candidate and target PDBs to the Haddock node and run docking.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Structures
docs.text:
1. Use the Load PDB node to load candidate and target protein structures.
  2. Ensure only one target PDB is provided (batching not supported for target).

docs.title: 2. Configure Docking Parameters
docs.text:
1. Optionally edit the TOML configuration for HADDOCK.
  2. Specify interface residues and chains if required.

docs.title: 3. Run Docking
docs.text:
1. Connect all required inputs and execute the node.
  2. Review outputs: best docking, all dockings, and scores table.

docs.title: Standard Docking
docs.text:
• Dock a single candidate protein against a single target protein.
  • Specify interface residues and chains for precise docking.
  • Use default or custom HADDOCK configuration.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example candidate_pdb Candidate protein structure to dock. PDB {"design_0": "..."} target_pdb Target protein structure to dock against (must be a single PDB). PDB {"target": "..."} docking_inputs_config HADDOCK configuration parameters in TOML format. STRING see below target_specs Residue numbers in the target protein defining the binding interface. STRING 1,2,3 candidate_specs Residue numbers in the candidate protein defining the binding interface. STRING 10,11,12 candidate_chains Chains in the candidate protein to consider for docking. STRING A,B target_chains Chains in the target protein to consider for docking. STRING A mode Execution mode: MOCK, PROD, or TEST. STRING PROD

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example best.pdb Best of the predicted dockings. {"design_0": "..."} bound.pdb All predicted dockings. {"design_0_model1": "..."} scores.csv Docking scores table (caprieval statistics). CSV string

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use high-quality, properly formatted PDB files for both candidate and target.
  • Ensure only one target PDB is provided per run.

docs.title: Docking Configuration
docs.text:
• Adjust interface residues and chains for more accurate docking.
  • Use TEST mode for quick validation with minimal sampling.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Multiple target PDBs provided: Only one target protein is supported. Use Load PDB to select a single target.
  • Docking fails or returns empty results: Check that input PDBs are valid and interface residues/chains are correctly specified.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• HADDOCK documentation
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Immunogenicity B Cell Epiptope
docs.text: Runs immunogenicity B-cell epitope evaluation on a batch of protein structures, predicting potential immunogenic regions using a sliding window approach.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your protein structure(s) in PDB format.
  2. Set the desired window size for epitope prediction.
  3. Run the node to obtain immunogenicity scores as a CSV table.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Ensure your protein structures are available in PDB format.
  2. Load the PDB(s) using the appropriate node (e.g., Load PDB).

docs.title: 2. Configure Node Parameters
docs.text:
1. Specify the window size for the sliding window (default: 10).
  2. (Optional) Adjust the mode for testing or mock runs if needed.

docs.title: 3. Run the Node
docs.text:
1. Connect the required inputs and execute the node.
  2. Review the output CSV for immunogenicity scores.

docs.title: Predicting B-cell Epitope Immunogenicity
docs.text:
• Input one or more PDB structures.
  • Set the window size to define the peptide length for prediction.
  • Obtain a CSV table with immunogenicity scores for each input structure.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Structures to evaluate. PDB {"sample1": "...PDB content..."} window_size Sliding window size to construct peptides for prediction. INT 10

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example score.csv Immunogenicity scores of the proteins. CSV file with scores

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure PDB files are properly formatted and contain valid protein structures.
  • Use unique identifiers for each structure to avoid confusion in output tables.

docs.title: Parameter Selection
docs.text:
• Choose a window size appropriate for the epitope length relevant to your study.
  • For typical B-cell epitope prediction, a window size of 10 is standard, but adjust as needed.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty or malformed PDB input: Ensure all input structures are valid and correctly formatted.
  • No scores in output: Check that the window size is appropriate and input structures are not empty.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Immunogenicity Class 1
docs.text: Runs immunogenicity class 1 evaluation on the provided batch of proteins, predicting MHC class I binding and immunogenicity scores.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect a PDB batch to the node's input.
  2. Specify the MHC class I allele and window size as needed.
  3. Run the node to obtain immunogenicity scores as a CSV.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Generate or load protein structures in PDB format.
  2. Ensure each structure has a unique identifier.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node Parameters
docs.text:
1. Set the c_allele to the desired MHC class I allele (e.g., HLA-A0101).
  2. Adjust c_window_size for the sliding window (default: 9).

docs.title: 3. Run Evaluation
docs.text: 1. Connect the node in your workflow and execute to receive results.

docs.title: Immunogenicity Scoring
docs.text:
• Predicts immunogenicity for each input protein structure.
  • Supports batch processing of multiple PDBs.
  • Outputs a merged CSV table of scores.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Structures to evaluate. PDB See PDB doc c_allele MHC class I allele forming the pMHCI complex for prediction. STRING HLA-A0101 c_window_size Sliding window size for peptide binding prediction. INT 9

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example score.csv Immunogenicity scores of proteins. See CSV output

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use well-formed PDB files with unique IDs for each structure.
  • Choose the appropriate MHC allele relevant to your study.

docs.title: Parameter Selection
docs.text:
• Default window size (9) is suitable for most MHC class I predictions.
  • Adjust window size only if you have specific requirements.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty or invalid PDB input: Ensure all input structures are valid and uniquely identified.
  • Incorrect allele format: Use standard allele names (e.g., HLA-A0101).

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Immunogenicity MHC 2
docs.text: Runs immunogenicity MHC class II evaluation on a batch of protein structures, predicting peptide binding and immunogenicity scores for specified MHC II alleles.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect a PDB batch to the node's input.
  2. Specify the MHC class II allele and window size as needed.
  3. Run the node to obtain immunogenicity scores as a CSV table.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Generate or load protein structures in PDB format.
  2. Ensure all structures are properly formatted and batch IDs are unique.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node Parameters
docs.text:
1. Set the allele_name to the desired MHC II allele (e.g., DRB1*01:01).
  2. Adjust window_size (default: 15) to control the sliding window for peptide prediction.

docs.title: 3. Run and Retrieve Results
docs.text:
1. Execute the node in your workflow.
  2. Download or inspect the resulting immunogenicity scores CSV.

docs.title: Immunogenicity Scoring
docs.text:
• Predicts MHC II immunogenicity for each input protein structure.
  • Supports batch processing of multiple PDBs.
  • Outputs a merged CSV table with scores for all provided structures.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Structures to evaluate. PDB See PDB docs allele_name MHC class II allele for peptide binding prediction. STRING DRB1*01:01 window_size Sliding window size for peptide prediction (11–30, default: 15). INT 15

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example score.csv Immunogenicity scores of the proteins. See below

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use unique IDs for each PDB in a batch to avoid result merging issues.
  • Validate PDB formatting before running the node.

docs.title: Parameter Selection
docs.text:
• Choose allele_name relevant to your biological context.
  • Adjust window_size based on peptide length of interest (typically 15 for MHC II).

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty or malformed PDB input: Ensure all input structures are valid and non-empty.
  • Incorrect allele name: Use standard allele nomenclature (e.g., DRB1*01:01).
  • Window size out of range: Set window_size between 11 and 30.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Prodigy
docs.text: Predicts the binding affinity of protein-protein complexes using structural and interface analysis.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare a PDB file of your protein complex.
  2. Specify the chains to analyze (e.g., A;B for two molecules).
  3. Set temperature and optional thresholds as needed.
  4. Run the node to obtain binding affinity metrics.

docs.title: 1. Input Preparation
docs.text:
1. Ensure your protein complex is in PDB format.
  2. Identify chain IDs for each molecule or group.

docs.title: 2. Node Configuration
docs.text:
1. Enter the PDB structure and chain selection string.
  2. Adjust temperature, distance cutoff, and accessibility threshold as required.

docs.title: Binding Affinity Prediction
docs.text:
• Predicts binding affinity (ΔG, Kd) for protein complexes.
  • Supports custom chain grouping for multi-chain complexes.
  • Outputs a CSV table with detailed interface metrics.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Target protein complex to predict binding affinity for. PDB complex.pdb chains Chains to consider; semicolon separates molecules, comma groups chains. STRING A;B;C or A,B;C temperature Temperature (°C) for Kd prediction. INT 25 distance_cutoff Distance cutoff (Å) to calculate interface contacts. FLOAT 5.5 acc_threshold Accessibility threshold for BSA analysis. FLOAT 0.05

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example score.csv Table with binding scores (binding_affinity, kd, contacts, contact_types, nis_a, nis_c, temperature) score.csv

docs.title: Chain Selection
docs.text:
• Use semicolons to separate different molecules (e.g., A;B).
  • Use commas to group chains as a single molecule (e.g., A,B;C).

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Adjust distance_cutoff and acc_threshold for specific interface definitions.
  • Set temperature to match experimental or physiological conditions.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Incorrect chain selection: Double-check chain IDs and grouping format.
  • Empty or invalid PDB input: Ensure the PDB file is valid and contains the specified chains.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Prodigy web server documentation
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Chroma
docs.text: Runs inference of a Chroma model for protein structure generation, supporting both conditional and unconditional modes with extensive control over SDE integration parameters.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Set the desired number of integration steps and chain length.
  2. (Optional) Provide an initial PDB for conditional generation.
  3. Adjust SDE and Langevin parameters as needed.
  4. Run the node to generate protein structures.

docs.title: 1. Basic Configuration
docs.text:
1. Choose the number of integration steps (steps) and chain length (chain_length).
  2. Set SDE parameters such as tspan, langevin_factor, and inverse_temperature.
  3. (Optional) Provide an initial PDB for conditional generation.

docs.title: 2. Advanced Options
docs.text:
1. Select integration and SDE functions (integrate_func, sde_func).
  2. Configure output options like trajectory_length and full_output.
  3. Use chain manipulation options if needed (swap_chain_names, order_chain_names).

docs.title: Unconditional Generation
docs.text:
• Leave input_pdb empty to generate new protein structures from scratch.
  • Set chain_length and steps to control output size and detail.

docs.title: Conditional Generation
docs.text:
• Provide an input_pdb to guide the generation process.
  • Use chain manipulation options to adjust output chain order or names.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example steps Number of integration steps for the SDE. INT 500 chain_length Length of the protein chain. INT 100 tspan Time span for SDE integration (comma-separated floats). STRING 1.0,0.001 langevin_factor Strength of Langevin noise. FLOAT 2.0 langevin_isothermal Use isothermal Langevin SDE. BOOLEAN False inverse_temperature Inverse temperature parameter for SDE. FLOAT 10.0 initialize_noise Initialize noise for SDE integration. BOOLEAN True integrate_func Integration function to use. COMBO euler_maruyama sde_func SDE function to use. COMBO reverse_sde trajectory_length Number of steps in trajectory output (max: steps). INT 200 full_output Return full SDE integration outputs. BOOLEAN False swap_chain_names Comma-separated chain names to swap after generation. STRING A,B order_chain_names Comma-separated chain names to specify output order. STRING A,B seed Base seed for randomness. INT 42 mode Execution mode: MOCK, PROD, or TEST. COMBO PROD

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example input_pdb Initial PDB to start generation from. PDB {"1abc": "..."}

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example generation.pdb Generation result. PDB {"gen_0": "..."} trajectory.pdb Trajectory PDB (if full_output is True). PDB {"traj_0": "..."} Xhat_trajectory.pdb Xhat trajectory PDB (if full_output is True). PDB {"xhat_0": "..."} Xunc_trajectory.pdb Xunc trajectory PDB (if full_output is True). PDB {"xunc_0": "..."}

docs.title: Parameter Selection
docs.text:
• Start with default parameters for most use cases.
  • Increase steps and trajectory_length for higher resolution outputs.

docs.title: Reproducibility & Modes
docs.text:
• Use the same seed for reproducible results.
  • Use MOCK mode for workflow validation, TEST for quick checks, and PROD for full runs.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Output is empty or missing: Ensure all required parameters are set and input PDB (if used) is valid.
  • Long runtime: Reduce steps or use TEST mode for faster execution.
  • Chain manipulation not working: Check that chain names are valid and comma-separated.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Genie 2
docs.text: Runs inference of a Genie 2 model for protein generation, supporting both unconditional and motif/multimotif scaffolding. Fully reproducible, with flexible control over sequence length and motif placement.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Select the desired checkpoint (40-epoch for unconditional, 30-epoch for motif scaffolding).
  2. Set minimum and maximum sequence lengths.
  3. (Optional) Provide input PDB and contigs for motif scaffolding.
  4. Run the node to generate protein structures.

docs.title: 1. Unconditional Generation
docs.text:
1. Leave input_pdb and contigs empty.
  2. Set min_length, max_length, and length_step for desired sequence range.
  3. Choose checkpoint (recommended: 40-epoch).

docs.title: 2. Motif/Multimotif Scaffolding
docs.text:
1. Provide an input_pdb containing the motif(s).
  2. Define contigs to specify motif and flexible regions (e.g., A367-372/10-10/A342-348).
  3. Set min_length and max_length (used for motif scaffolding as well).
  4. Choose checkpoint (recommended: 30-epoch).

docs.title: Unconditional Generation
docs.text:
• Generate proteins of varying lengths without motifs.
  • Use for de novo protein design.

docs.title: Motif Scaffolding
docs.text:
• Scaffold one or more motifs into generated proteins.
  • Specify motif positions and flexible regions using contigs.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example checkpoint Checkpoint name. Use 40-epoch for unconditional, 30-epoch for motif scaffolding. COMBO base/epoch.40 scale Sampling noise scale. FLOAT 0.6 batch_size Batch size. Reduce if running out of GPU memory. INT 1 min_length Minimum sequence length. INT 100 max_length Maximum sequence length. INT 100 length_step Sequence length step size (unconditional only). INT 5 contigs Scaffold structure: fixed motifs (A10-25), flexible regions (5-15), explicit motif groups (A, B, etc.). See Setup Guide for format. STRING A367-372/10-10/A342-348 seed Base seed for randomness. INT 42

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example input_pdb Initial PDB to start generation from (scaffolding) PDB {"motif1": "...PDB..."}

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example generation.pdb Generation result. {"design_0": "..."} motif.pdb Generation motif pdb. {"motif1": "..."}

docs.title: Checkpoint Selection
docs.text:
• Use 40-epoch checkpoint for unconditional generation.
  • Use 30-epoch checkpoint for motif/multimotif scaffolding.

docs.title: Contigs Formatting
docs.text:
• For motif scaffolding, clearly define motif and flexible regions in contigs.
  • Use explicit motif groups (A, B, etc.) for multimotif tasks.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No lengths generated: Ensure min_length ≤ max_length and length_step is positive.
  • Missing contigs for scaffolding: For motif scaffolding, both input_pdb and contigs must be provided.
  • Chain breaks not supported: All segments in contigs are sequentially connected; do not use chain breaks.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: RFDiffusionContigmapConfig
docs.text: Provides interface for passing contigmap configuration to RF Diffusion node.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the RFDiffusionContigmapConfig node to your workflow.
  2. Specify masking and unmasking regions as needed for your design.
  3. Connect the output to the RF Diffusion node's contigmap_config input.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Insert the RFDiffusionContigmapConfig node from the node palette.
  2. Connect it to the contigmap_config input of the RF Diffusion node.

docs.title: 2. Configure Parameters
docs.text:
1. Set masking and unmasking regions using the input fields:
    • Use the same format as for contigs (e.g., A10-25, 5-15).
    • Leave fields empty if not required.

docs.title: Masking Sequence Regions
docs.text:
• Use inpaint_seq to mask specific amino acid sequence regions.
  • Use inpaint_str to mask 3D structure indices.
  • Use provide_seq to unmask specific sequence regions.
  • Use length to define the length or range for the region.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example inpaint_seq Amino acids whose sequence should be masked (contigs format). STRING A10-25 inpaint_str Indices for masking the 3D structure. STRING B165-178 provide_seq Inclusive ranges of sequence regions to unmask. STRING 172-177,200-205 length Length or range of sequence length. STRING 100 or 100-150

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example contigmap_config Configuration dict for RF Diffusion node. {"inpaint_seq": ["A10-25"], ...}

docs.title: Parameter Formatting
docs.text:
• Use the same format as for RF Diffusion contigs (e.g., A10-25, 5-15).
  • Leave fields empty if not needed for your use case.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text: • Always connect this node to the contigmap_config input of the RF Diffusion node for advanced masking/unmasking.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Incorrect format in input fields: Ensure you use the correct contigs format (e.g., A10-25).
  • Unexpected results in RF Diffusion: Double-check that masking/unmasking regions are specified as intended.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• See the RF Diffusion documentation for more details on contigmap configuration.
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: RF Diffusion Denoiser Config
docs.text: Provides interface for passing denoiser configuration parameters to the RF Diffusion node.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the RF Diffusion Denoiser Config node to your workflow.
  2. Set the noise and schedule parameters as needed for your design.
  3. Connect the output to the denoiser_config input of the RF Diffusion node.

docs.title: 1. Insert Node
docs.text:
1. Drag the RF Diffusion Denoiser Config node into your workflow.
  2. Connect it to the RF Diffusion node where advanced denoiser configuration is required.

docs.title: 2. Configure Parameters
docs.text:
1. Adjust noise scales and schedule types for CA and frame as needed.
  2. Save and run the workflow.

docs.title: Customizing Denoiser Settings
docs.text:
• Use to fine-tune noise parameters for translation and rotation during diffusion.
  • Useful for advanced users optimizing generation quality or speed.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example noise_scale_ca Scales the amount of noise to add to translations at the initial (t=T) step. FLOAT 1.0 final_noise_scale_ca Scales the noise for translations at the final (t=1) step. FLOAT 1.0 ca_noise_schedule_type Function to interpolate between noiseT and noise1 for translations. COMBO constant noise_scale_frame Scales the noise for rotations at the initial (t=T) step. FLOAT 1.0 final_noise_scale_frame Scales the noise for rotations at the final (t=1) step. FLOAT 1.0 frame_noise_schedule_type Function to interpolate between noiseT and noise1 for rotations. COMBO constant

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example denoiser_config Configuration dict for RF Diffusion node. {"noise_scale_ca":1.0,...}

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Start with default values for most use cases.
  • Increase noise scales for more diversity, decrease for more stability.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Only use this node if you need to override default denoiser settings in RF Diffusion.
  • Connect directly to the denoiser_config input of the RF Diffusion node.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Unexpected results: Try reverting to default parameter values.
  • Node not connected: Ensure the output is linked to the correct RF Diffusion input.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• See the RF Diffusion documentation for integration examples.
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: RF Diffusion Potentials Config
docs.text: Provides interface for passing potential configuration to the RF Diffusion node, enabling advanced control over guiding potentials and related parameters.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the RF Diffusion Potentials Config node to your workflow.
  2. Specify guiding potentials and other parameters as needed.
  3. Connect the output to the RF Diffusion node's potentials_config input.

docs.title: 1. Insert Node
docs.text:
1. Drag the RF Diffusion Potentials Config node into your workflow.
  2. Connect it to the RF Diffusion node.

docs.title: 2. Configure Potentials
docs.text:
1. Define guiding potentials using the provided string format.
  2. Adjust scale, decay, and other options as required for your design.

docs.title: Example Use Cases
docs.text:
• Add monomer or oligomer contact potentials to guide protein generation.
  • Fine-tune the influence of potentials with scale and decay settings.
  • Specify custom contacts or substrate-based potentials for advanced scenarios.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example guiding_potentials Semicolon-separated list of potentials. Each: type:potential_type,arg1:val1,arg2:val2,... Supported types and args in tooltip. STRING type:monomer_ROG,weight:1,min_dist:5;type:olig_contacts,weight_intra:1,weight_inter:0.1 guide_scale Scale factor for applying guiding potentials. INT 10 guide_decay Decay type for applying guiding potentials. COMBO constant olig_inter_all Whether all off-diagonal elements have contact potential. BOOLEAN False olig_intra_all Whether all on-diagonal elements have contact potential. BOOLEAN False olig_custom_contact Comma-separated contacts between chain pairs (! = repulsive, & = attractive). STRING A!B,B&C substrate Ligand residue name in input PDB for substrate-based potentials. STRING LLK

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example potentials_config Configuration dict for RF Diffusion node. { ... }

docs.title: Defining Potentials
docs.text:
• Use clear, supported types and argument names for each potential.
  • Combine multiple potentials with semicolons for complex guidance.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Start with default scale and decay, then adjust for desired effect.
  • Use custom contacts and substrate only when required for your design.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Invalid potential format: Ensure each potential follows the required type:arg1:val1,... format and is separated by semicolons.
  • Unsupported potential type: Check tooltip for supported types and arguments.
  • No effect from potentials: Verify that the config is connected to the RF Diffusion node and parameters are set correctly.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Refer to the node tooltip for supported potential types and argument details.
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: RF Diffusion Symmetry Config
docs.text: Provides interface for passing symmetry configuration to the RF Diffusion node, enabling advanced control over symmetric protein complex generation.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the RF Diffusion Symmetry Config node to your workflow.
  2. Set the desired symmetry type (e.g., c2, d5, tetrahedral).
  3. Adjust radius and other parameters as needed.
  4. Connect the output to the RF Diffusion node's symmetry_config input.

docs.title: 1. Insert Node
docs.text:
1. Drag the RF Diffusion Symmetry Config node into your workflow.
  2. Connect it to the RF Diffusion node where advanced symmetry is required.

docs.title: 2. Configure Parameters
docs.text:
1. Choose the symmetry type (e.g., c2 for cyclic, d5 for dihedral, or polyhedral types).
  2. Set the radius and other options to match your design goals.

docs.title: Symmetric Protein Generation
docs.text:
• Use to enforce cyclic, dihedral, or polyhedral symmetry in generated protein complexes.
  • Adjust radius to control subunit placement.
  • Enable or disable recentering and self-conditioning as needed.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example symmetry Type of symmetry to sample. Accepts cyclic (e.g., c2), dihedral (e.g., d5), tetrahedral, octahedral, or icosahedral. STRING c2 recenter Whether to reposition the complex so its center aligns with the origin. BOOLEAN True radius Distance from symmetry center to subunit positions. INT 10 model_only_neighbors Model only neighboring subunits of the asymmetric unit. BOOLEAN False symmetric_self_cond Enforce symmetry during intermediate diffusion steps. BOOLEAN True

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example symmetry_config Configuration dict to be passed to RF Diffusion. {"symmetry": "c2", ...}

docs.title: Symmetry Selection
docs.text:
• Use cyclic (cN) for ring-like assemblies, dihedral (dN) for double rings, or polyhedral types for complex symmetries.
  • Validate that the chosen symmetry matches your biological or design intent.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Adjust radius to avoid steric clashes between subunits.
  • Enable recentering for better coordinate alignment in downstream analysis.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Invalid symmetry type: Ensure the symmetry string matches accepted formats (e.g., c2, d5, tetrahedral).
  • Unexpected geometry: Adjust radius or check input structure for compatibility with the chosen symmetry.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• See the RF Diffusion documentation for more details on symmetry configuration.
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: RF Diffusion
docs.text: Runs inference of a RF Diffusion model (conditional or unconditional) for protein structure generation.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Select the appropriate checkpoint or use "Auto" for automatic selection.
  2. Specify the generation mode by setting contigs (length range for unconditional, motif/gap layout for conditional).
  3. (Optional) Provide an input PDB for conditional generation.
  4. Adjust other parameters as needed (e.g., write_trajectory, final_step).
  5. Run the node to generate protein structures.

docs.title: 1. Unconditional Generation
docs.text:
1. Set contigs to a length range (e.g., 100-100).
  2. Leave input_pdb empty.
  3. Configure other parameters as desired.

docs.title: 2. Conditional Generation (Motif Scaffolding)
docs.text:
1. Set contigs to specify fixed motifs and flexible gaps (e.g., 5-15/A10-25/30-40/0 B1-100).
  2. Provide an input_pdb containing the motif.
  3. (Optional) Connect additional configuration nodes for symmetry, contigmap, denoiser, or potentials.

docs.title: Unconditional Generation
docs.text:
• Generate novel protein backbones of specified length.
  • Use for de novo protein design.

docs.title: Motif Scaffolding
docs.text:
• Scaffold a fixed motif within a generated backbone.
  • Specify complex layouts with flexible regions and chain breaks.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example checkpoint Checkpoint name or "Auto" for automatic selection. COMBO Auto write_trajectory Whether to include the protein sample trajectory. BOOLEAN True model_runner Sampler name. COMBO SelfConditioning align_motif Align the model's prediction of the motif to the input motif. BOOLEAN True final_step Step to stop reverse diffusion (higher = faster, less accurate). INT 1 contigs Sequence layout: length range (unconditional) or motif/gap layout (conditional). STRING 100-100 or 5-15/A10-25 hotspot_res Residues on the target protein to involve in inference (comma-separated). STRING A30,A33,A34 seed Base seed for randomness. INT 42 mode Node execution mode: MOCK, PROD, or TEST. COMBO PROD

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example input_pdb Initial PDB to start generation from (for conditional generation). PDB symmetry_config Additional symmetry configuration (from RFDiffusionSymmetryConfig node). JSON contigmap_config Additional contigmap configuration (from RFDiffusionContigmapConfig node). JSON denoiser_config Additional denoiser configuration (from RFDiffusionDenoiserConfig node). JSON potentials_config Additional potentials configuration (from RFDiffusionPotentialsConfig node). JSON

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example generation.pdb Generation result. PDB trajectory_Xt-1.pdb Xt-1 trajectory PDB (if write_trajectory is True). PDB trajectory_pX0.pdb pX0 trajectory PDB (if write_trajectory is True). PDB

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• For unconditional generation, specify only a length range in contigs and leave input_pdb empty.
  • For motif scaffolding, provide both a motif-containing input_pdb and a detailed contigs string.

docs.title: Advanced Configuration
docs.text:
• Use configuration nodes for symmetry, contigmap, denoiser, or potentials to fine-tune generation.
  • Start with MOCK or TEST mode to validate setup before running full PROD jobs.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Error: Non-empty contigs must be passed: Ensure you specify a valid length range or motif/gap layout.
  • Error: For unconditional sampling, expected contigs to specify only length range: Remove motifs or chain breaks from contigs.
  • Error: For conditional sampling, expected contigs to specify at least one fixed region: Add a motif region (e.g., A10-25) to contigs.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• See RF Diffusion documentation for model details.
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Alphafold Initial Guess
docs.text: Predicts binder structure from sequence and an initial guess structure, initializing Alphafold with binder atoms to ensure proper binding during folding.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare matching FASTA and PDB files (IDs must correspond).
  2. Set desired parameters (e.g., recycles, monomer mode).
  3. Run the node to generate predicted foldings and scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Ensure FASTA and PDB records have matching IDs for batch processing.
  2. Adjust sequence and structure as needed for your design.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Set maintain_res_numbering to preserve residue numbering if required.
  2. Adjust max_amide_dist, recycle, and force_monomer as needed.
  3. Enable debug for strict error handling.

docs.title: Single or Batch Prediction
docs.text:
• Use for single or multiple sequence/structure pairs.
  • Useful for binder design and initial structure refinement.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example fasta Sequences to run through the model. IDs must match PDBs for batch. FASTA ">id1\nSEQUENCE" pdb Structures to run through the model. IDs must match FASTA for batch. PDB "{id1: pdb_content}" maintain_res_numbering Do not renumber residues on bad input. BOOLEAN False max_amide_dist Max distance between amide bond's carbon and nitrogen. FLOAT 3.0 recycle Number of AF2 recycles to perform. INT 3 force_monomer Predict structure as monomer. BOOLEAN False debug Crash on errors if True, continue otherwise. BOOLEAN True

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example folding.pdb Predicted foldings. "{id1: pdb_content}" score.sc Scores of the designs (rmsd, pae, plddt). "rmsd: 1.2, plddt: 85"

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure FASTA and PDB IDs match for batch processing.
  • Use high-quality initial structures for better results.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Adjust recycle for accuracy vs. speed.
  • Use force_monomer for monomeric predictions only.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Mismatched IDs: Ensure FASTA and PDB record IDs correspond exactly.
  • Unexpected output: Check input formats and parameter values.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Alphafold
docs.text: Runs Alphafold model inference on MSA search results and generates 5 pdb foldings per input sample ranked by best score.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare MSA search results in A3M format.
  2. Select model and configuration options.
  3. Run the node to generate ranked protein structure predictions.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Obtain MSA search results in A3M format (e.g., using the MSA Search node).
  2. Ensure input IDs are unique and correspond to your samples.

docs.title: 2. Configure Alphafold Node
docs.text:
1. Choose model preset and relaxation options as needed.
  2. Set additional parameters (e.g., skip models, seed).

docs.title: 3. Run Prediction
docs.text: 1. Execute the node to obtain ranked PDB foldings for each input.

docs.title: Single Sequence Prediction
docs.text:
• Input a single A3M record to predict its structure.
  • Use default model and settings for standard monomer prediction.

docs.title: Batch Prediction
docs.text:
• Input multiple A3M records for batch structure prediction.
  • Each input will yield 5 ranked PDB outputs.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example a3m MSA search results in a3m format. A3M {"sample1": "..."} search_templates Whether to search for available templates before prediction. BOOLEAN False model_preset Which Alphafold model to run. COMBO monomer models_to_relax Whether to run relaxation step (not supported yet). COMBO NONE enable_gpu_relax Whether to run relaxation step on GPU or CPU. BOOLEAN True skip_models Which models to skip (comma-separated indices 1-5). STRING 3,5 seed Base seed for randomness. INT 42 mode Mode to run the node in (MOCK, PROD, TEST). COMBO PROD

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example folding.pdb Ranked foldings as a dict {pdb_id_rank_id: pdb_content}. PDB {"sample1_ranked_0": "..."}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure A3M input records are correctly formatted and IDs are unique.
  • Use the MSA Search node for compatible input generation.

docs.title: Model Selection
docs.text:
• Use the default monomer model for standard predictions.
  • Only skip models if you need to speed up inference and understand the implications.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• All models skipped: Cannot skip all 5 models; remove at least one from skip_models.
  • Relaxation not supported: Relaxation step is not implemented; set models_to_relax to NONE.
  • Multimer not supported: Multimer model is not available; use monomer presets.
  • Input ID mismatch: Ensure input IDs in A3M and FASTA match exactly.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Alphafold documentation
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Boltz-2 Complex Molecular Assembly
docs.text: Boltz-2 Complex Molecular Assembly enables the joint prediction and assembly of multi-component biomolecular complexes, including proteins, DNA, RNA, and ligands, with optional constraints and affinity prediction.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare FASTA sequences for each molecular component (protein, DNA, RNA) as needed.
  2. (Optional) Provide ligand SMILES or CCD codes, and custom MSAs for proteins.
  3. (Optional) Specify binding or contact constraints.
  4. Set prediction parameters (e.g., recycling steps, diffusion samples).
  5. Run the node to generate assembled complex structures and confidence/affinity scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Molecular Inputs
docs.text:
1. Collect and format protein, DNA, RNA sequences in FASTA format.
  2. List ligand SMILES or CCD codes (one per line).
  3. (Optional) Prepare A3M MSAs for proteins.

docs.title: 2. Configure Assembly and Constraints
docs.text:
1. (Optional) Define binding or contact constraints as described in the node UI.
  2. (Optional) Enable affinity prediction and specify binder chain if needed.
  3. Adjust prediction parameters (recycling steps, diffusion samples, etc.).

docs.title: Multi-Component Assembly
docs.text:
• Assemble complexes from any combination of proteins, DNA, RNA, and ligands.
  • Optionally provide MSAs for improved protein modeling.
  • Apply binding/contact constraints to guide assembly.
  • Predict binding affinity for ligand-containing complexes.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example seed Random seed for reproducibility INT 42

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text:
Field Description Type Example protein_sequences Protein sequences in FASTA format FASTA >A
MKVL...
>B
GYLL... dna_sequences DNA sequences in FASTA format FASTA >DNA1
ATCG... rna_sequences RNA sequences in FASTA format FASTA >RNA1
AUCGA... ligand_smiles Ligand SMILES strings (one per line) STRING CCO
CC(=O)O ligand_ccd_codes Ligand CCD codes (one per line) STRING ATP
GTP protein_msas Custom MSAs for proteins A3M {"A": "..."} binding_constraints Binding constraints (see UI) STRING A:B:10,20 contact_constraints Contact constraints (see UI) STRING A:10-B:20 predict_affinity Enable binding affinity prediction BOOLEAN True affinity_binder_chain Chain ID for affinity calculation STRING L1 recycling_steps Number of recycling iterations INT 3 diffusion_samples Number of structure samples INT 1 use_potentials Use potentials for improved accuracy BOOLEAN False output_format Output file format COMBO pdb

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example structures.pdb Assembled complex structures (ranked) {"A": "...PDB..."} confidence.json Confidence scores for predictions {"A": 0.92} affinity.json Binding affinity scores (if enabled) {"A": -7.5}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Provide high-quality, correctly formatted FASTA sequences for all components.
  • Supply MSAs for proteins when possible to improve structure accuracy.

docs.title: Constraints & Affinity
docs.text:
• Use binding/contact constraints to guide specific interactions.
  • Enable affinity prediction only when ligands are present and specify the correct binder chain.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Missing molecular components: At least one protein, DNA, RNA, or ligand must be provided.
  • MSA not provided: Results may be lower quality for proteins without MSAs.
  • Affinity prediction error: Ensure at least one ligand is present and binder chain is specified or auto-detectable.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Boltz-2 Protein-Ligand Complex Prediction
docs.text: Predicts the structure and binding affinity of protein-ligand complexes using the Boltz-2 model. Supports both separate protein/ligand inputs and pre-formed complex PDBs.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Select input mode: separate components or complex PDB.
  2. Provide protein (A3M or FASTA) and ligand (SMILES or CCD) or upload a complex PDB.
  3. Set prediction parameters as needed.
  4. Run the node to obtain predicted structures, confidence, and affinity scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Choose input mode: separate_components (default) or complex_pdb.
  2. For separate_components, provide:
  3. Protein sequence (A3M or FASTA)
  4. Ligand (SMILES string or CCD code)
  5. For complex_pdb, upload a pre-formed protein-ligand complex PDB.

docs.title: 2. Configure Prediction
docs.text:
1. Adjust optional parameters (recycling steps, diffusion samples, output format, etc.) as needed.
  2. Enable or disable binding affinity prediction.

docs.title: Predicting Protein-Ligand Complex Structure
docs.text:
• Use separate_components mode for de novo prediction from sequence/MSA and ligand.
  • Use complex_pdb mode to refine or score an existing complex.
  • Adjust recycling_steps for quality vs. speed.
  • Set diffusion_samples >1 for diverse predictions.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example input_mode Input mode: separate components or PDB STRING separate_components seed Random seed for reproducibility INT 42

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example protein_input_type Protein input type: a3m or fasta STRING a3m protein_a3m Protein MSA (single-entry dict) A3M {"A": "..."} protein_fasta Protein FASTA sequence FASTA ">A\nMKT..." ligand_type Ligand input type: smiles or ccd STRING smiles ligand_smiles Ligand SMILES string STRING CCO ligand_ccd Ligand CCD code STRING ATP complex_pdb Pre-formed protein-ligand complex PDB {"complex": "..."} recycling_steps Number of recycling iterations INT 3 diffusion_samples Number of structure samples to generate INT 1 predict_affinity Predict binding affinity BOOLEAN True use_potentials Use potentials for improved quality BOOLEAN False output_format Output format: pdb or mmcif STRING pdb

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example structures.pdb Predicted protein-ligand complex structures {"A": "..."} confidence.json Confidence scores for predictions {"A": 0.92} affinity.json Predicted binding affinity metrics {"A": -7.1}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use high-quality MSA (A3M) for best structure prediction results.
  • Provide chemically valid SMILES or correct CCD codes for ligands.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Increase recycling_steps for higher accuracy (at the cost of speed).
  • Use multiple diffusion_samples to explore structural diversity.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Missing or invalid input: Ensure all required fields are provided and correctly formatted.
  • Low confidence or affinity scores: Try increasing recycling steps or providing better MSA/ligand data.
  • Affinity prediction fails: Confirm ligand is present and correctly specified.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Boltz-2 Protein Structure Prediction
docs.text: Predicts 3D protein structures from MSA (A3M) and FASTA using the Boltz-2 model. Supports batch prediction, confidence scoring, and reproducible sampling.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your protein FASTA sequence and MSA (A3M format).
  2. Set the desired number of structure samples and recycling steps.
  3. Run the node to generate ranked structure predictions and confidence scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Obtain the target protein's FASTA sequence.
  2. Run MSA search to generate A3M input (e.g., with MSA Search node).

docs.title: 2. Configure Prediction
docs.text:
1. Set recycling_steps for quality vs. speed.
  2. Choose diffusion_samples for diversity.
  3. Optionally adjust sampling_steps, use_potentials, and output_format.

docs.title: 3. Run and Retrieve Results
docs.text:
1. Execute the node.
  2. Download predicted structures and confidence scores from outputs.

docs.title: Single Protein Structure Prediction
docs.text:
• Input a single FASTA and A3M to predict structure.
  • Adjust recycling_steps for accuracy.
  • Use diffusion_samples >1 for diverse predictions.

docs.title: Batch Prediction
docs.text:
• Provide A3M with multiple entries to predict structures for each sequence.
  • Each output is indexed by input sequence ID.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example fasta Original protein FASTA sequence FASTA ">A\nMKT..." a3m MSA search results (A3M format) A3M {"A": "..."} seed Random seed for reproducibility INT 42

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example recycling_steps Number of recycling iterations INT 3 diffusion_samples Number of structure samples to generate INT 5 sampling_steps Steps for diffusion process INT 200 use_potentials Use potentials for higher quality BOOLEAN True output_format Output file format ("pdb" or "mmcif") STRING "pdb"

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example structures.pdb Ranked predicted structures (dict) {"A_rank_0": "..."} confidence.json Confidence scores for each prediction {"A_rank_0": 0.92}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use high-quality, full-length FASTA sequences.
  • Generate A3M using comprehensive MSA search for best results.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Increase recycling_steps for higher accuracy (at cost of speed).
  • Use diffusion_samples >1 to explore structural diversity.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Missing or empty FASTA/A3M: Ensure both inputs are provided and correctly formatted.
  • Low confidence scores: Try increasing recycling_steps or improving MSA quality.
  • Output is empty: Check input sequence IDs and formats.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Boltz-2 Structure Refinement
docs.text: Refines protein structures using Boltz-2 with inference-time potentials for improved accuracy and quality.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Provide a PDB structure as input.
  2. Set the desired random seed and optional refinement parameters.
  3. Run the node to generate refined structures and confidence scores.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input
docs.text:
1. Obtain or generate a PDB structure to refine.
  2. Ensure the structure is in the correct PDB dictionary format.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Set the seed for reproducibility (integer).
  2. Optionally adjust recycling steps, number of samples, and potentials usage.

docs.title: 3. Run Refinement
docs.text: 1. Execute the node to receive refined structures and confidence metrics.

docs.title: Refining a Predicted Structure
docs.text:
• Use after initial structure prediction to improve model quality.
  • Supports batch refinement by increasing diffusion_samples.
  • Recommended to keep use_potentials enabled for best results.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Input PDB structure to refine PDB {"design_0": "...PDB content..."} seed Random seed for reproducibility INT 42

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example recycling_steps Number of recycling iterations (higher = better quality) INT 3 diffusion_samples Number of refined structures to generate INT 3 use_potentials Use inference-time potentials (recommended) BOOLEAN True output_format Output file format COMBO ("pdb", "mmcif") "pdb"

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example refined_structures.pdb Refined structure(s) as a dict PDB {"design_0_ranked_0": "...PDB..."} confidence.json Confidence scores for each refined structure JSON {"design_0_ranked_0": 0.92}

docs.title: Refinement Settings
docs.text:
• Enable use_potentials for improved physical plausibility.
  • Increase recycling_steps for higher accuracy if runtime allows.

docs.title: Batch Processing
docs.text:
• Use higher diffusion_samples to explore multiple refined conformations.
  • Review confidence scores to select the best refined model.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Input format error: Ensure the PDB input is a dictionary with valid PDB content.
  • No output generated: Check that all required fields are provided and input is not empty.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Boltz-2 Virtual Screening
docs.text: Performs high-throughput virtual screening of small molecules against a target protein using Boltz-2, predicting binding affinity and ranking top candidates for drug discovery.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare the target protein FASTA sequence.
  2. List ligand SMILES strings (one per line).
  3. (Recommended) Provide a protein MSA (A3M format) for better accuracy.
  4. Set screening parameters as needed.
  5. Run the node to obtain ranked screening results.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Obtain the target protein FASTA sequence.
  2. Collect ligand SMILES strings (one per line).
  3. (Optional) Prepare ligand names and protein MSA (A3M).

docs.title: 2. Configure Screening
docs.text:
1. Adjust parameters such as top_k, affinity threshold, and batch size as needed.
  2. Enable or disable fast mode for speed/accuracy tradeoff.

docs.title: 3. Run and Review Results
docs.text:
1. Execute the node.
  2. Review the output JSON for ranked hits and predicted affinities.

docs.title: Virtual Screening Workflow
docs.text:
• Screen a library of small molecules against a protein target.
  • Filter hits by predicted affinity and binding probability.
  • Retrieve top-ranked ligands for further analysis.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example protein_fasta Target protein FASTA sequence FASTA ">A\nMKT..." ligand_smiles_list SMILES strings (one per line) STRING "CCO\nC1=CC=CC=C1" seed Random seed for reproducibility INT 42

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example top_k Number of top hits to return INT 10 affinity_threshold Affinity cutoff (log IC50) FLOAT -5.0 binding_prob_threshold Binding probability cutoff FLOAT 0.7 ligand_names Ligand names (one per line, matches SMILES) STRING "Aspirin\nIbuprofen" protein_msa Protein MSA (A3M format, recommended) A3M {"A": "..."} batch_size Number of ligands processed per batch INT 5 fast_mode Use faster settings for screening BOOLEAN True

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example screening_results.json Ranked screening results with affinities, scores {"hits": [...]}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Always provide a high-quality protein FASTA sequence.
  • Use realistic, valid SMILES strings for ligands.
  • Supplying a protein MSA (A3M) significantly improves prediction quality.

docs.title: Screening Parameters
docs.text:
• Adjust top_k and thresholds to balance hit rate and specificity.
  • Use fast_mode for rapid initial screening; disable for higher accuracy.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Missing or invalid FASTA/SMILES: Ensure all required fields are filled and formatted correctly.
  • No hits returned: Loosen affinity or probability thresholds, or check input quality.
  • Mismatch in ligand names and SMILES: Provide the same number of names as SMILES entries.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Colabfold Batch
docs.text:
This node is currently disabled.

Need access? Contact us and we’ll help you out.

Runs Colabfold model inference on Colabfold MSA search results, generating 5 ranked PDB foldings per input sample.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare MSA search results in A3M format using the Colabfold Search node.
  2. Connect the A3M output to the Colabfold Batch node.
  3. Run the node to generate ranked PDB foldings.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Use the Colabfold Search node to obtain MSA results in A3M format.
  2. Ensure each sequence is properly formatted and identified.

docs.title: 2. Run Colabfold Batch
docs.text:
1. Connect the A3M input to the Colabfold Batch node.
  2. Execute the node to receive ranked PDB foldings for each input sequence.

docs.title: Batch Structure Prediction
docs.text:
• Input a batch of A3M-formatted MSA results.
  • Obtain 5 ranked PDB foldings per input sample.
  • Use outputs for downstream analysis or visualization.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example a3m MSA search results in a3m format. A3M {"seq1": "...", "seq2": "..."}

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example folding.pdb Ranked foldings as a dict {pdb_id_rank_id: pdb_content}. PDB {"seq1_ranked_1": "...", "seq1_ranked_2": "..."}

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure A3M input is generated by the Colabfold Search node for compatibility.
  • Use clear, unique sequence IDs to avoid confusion in output mapping.

docs.title: Output Handling
docs.text:
• Use the ranked outputs for further evaluation or visualization.
  • Integrate with downstream nodes for workflow automation.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No output generated: Verify that the A3M input is correctly formatted and not empty.
  • Unexpected output IDs: Ensure input sequence IDs are unique and consistent.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Colabfold Search
docs.text:
This node is currently disabled.

Need access? Contact us and we’ll help you out.

Performs Colabfold MSA search on provided protein sequences against known sequence databases, returning results for each sequence in .a3m format as a dictionary {seq_id: a3m_content}.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
