1. Prepare your protein sequences in FASTA format.
  2. Connect the FASTA input to the Colabfold Search node.
  3. Run the node to obtain MSA search results in .a3m format.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input
docs.text:
1. Format your protein sequences as a valid FASTA string.
  2. Ensure each sequence has a unique identifier.

docs.title: 2. Run Colabfold Search
docs.text:
1. Connect the FASTA input to the node.
  2. Execute the node to perform the MSA search.

docs.title: Single or Batch MSA Search
docs.text:
• Accepts single or multiple protein sequences in FASTA format.
  • Returns a dictionary mapping each sequence ID to its .a3m MSA result.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example fasta Sequences to run Colabfold MSA search on. FASTA ">seq1\nMKT..."

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example msa.a3m Search results as a dict {seq_id: a3m_content}. { "seq1": "...a3m..." }

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Use clear, unique sequence IDs in your FASTA records.
  • Validate FASTA formatting to avoid processing errors.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Use the output .a3m directly as input for downstream structure prediction nodes (e.g., Alphafold, Boltz).
  • For batch processing, ensure all sequences are relevant to the same analysis context.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty or malformed FASTA input: Ensure your input is properly formatted and not empty.
  • Timeouts on large batches: For very large numbers of sequences, consider splitting into smaller batches.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• ColabFold documentation
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: MSA Search
docs.text: Performs MSA search on provided protein sequences against known sequence databases, returning results in unified .a3m format for each input sequence.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your input FASTA file with one or more protein sequences.
  2. Select the desired database preset (Toy, Reduced, or Full).
  3. Run the node to obtain MSA results in .a3m format for each sequence.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Format your protein sequences in standard FASTA format.
  2. Ensure each sequence has a unique identifier.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node Parameters
docs.text:
1. Choose the database preset according to your speed and accuracy needs.
  2. Set the mode (PROD for full search, MOCK for testing, TEST for quick checks).

docs.title: Single or Batch MSA Search
docs.text:
• Accepts single or multiple sequences in FASTA format.
  • Returns a dictionary mapping each sequence ID to its .a3m MSA result.
  • Supports quick testing with toy datasets for rapid iteration.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example fasta Sequences to run MSA search on. FASTA ">seq1\nMKT..." db_preset Dataset to perform MSA search on. COMBO "alphafold_reduced_dataset" mode Mode to run the node in. COMBO "PROD"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example msa.a3m Search results as a dict {seq_id: a3m_content}. {"seq1": "...a3m..."}

docs.title: Efficient Testing
docs.text:
• Use MOCK or TEST mode for rapid validation and debugging.
  • Start with the Toy dataset to ensure pipeline connectivity before running full searches.

docs.title: Database Selection
docs.text:
• Use the Reduced or Full database presets for production runs to maximize search coverage.
  • Choose the Toy preset for development or when working with short sequences.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Long runtime: Full database searches can take significant time; use Toy or Reduced presets for faster results.
  • Empty output: Ensure input FASTA is correctly formatted and contains valid sequences.
  • Mode confusion: If results look unexpected, verify the selected mode (MOCK, PROD, TEST).

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• MSA search documentation
  • FASTA format guide
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Rosetta Fast Relax
docs.text: Runs ProteinMPNN-FastRelax cycles on sequences and structures to make proteins more stable and realistic.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your input FASTA and PDB files with matching IDs.
  2. Set the desired number of relax cycles.
  3. Run the node to obtain relaxed protein structures.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Ensure your FASTA contains sequence records with IDs matching the PDB structure IDs.
  2. Ensure your PDB input contains structures with IDs matching the FASTA records.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node Parameters
docs.text:
1. Set the number of relax cycles (relax_cycles).
  2. Choose whether to enable debug mode (debug).

docs.title: Relaxing Protein Structures
docs.text:
• Use to improve stability and realism of predicted protein structures.
  • Batch process multiple sequence-structure pairs by matching IDs.
  • Useful after structure prediction or design steps.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example fasta Sequences to run through the model. IDs must match structure IDs. FASTA ">design_1\nMKT..." pdb Structures to run through the model. IDs must match sequence IDs. PDB "{design_1: ...}" relax_cycles Number of relax cycles to perform on each structure. INT 3 debug If true, errors will crash the script; if false, will skip failed poses. BOOLEAN true

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example structure.pdb Relaxed structures. PDB "{design_1: ...}"

docs.title: Input Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure FASTA and PDB IDs match exactly for correct pairing.
  • Use validated, high-quality input structures for best results.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Start with a low number of relax cycles for speed; increase for higher accuracy.
  • Enable debug mode during development to catch errors early.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Mismatched IDs: Ensure FASTA and PDB record IDs correspond exactly.
  • Node crashes on error: Set debug to false to skip failed poses instead of crashing.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Rosetta Fast Relax Paper
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: ProteinMPNN
docs.text: Predicts possible amino acid sequences for a given protein backbone, returning generated and top-scoring sequences.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your input PDB structure(s).
  2. Set the desired model parameters (e.g., model version, number of sequences).
  3. Connect the node and run to generate protein sequences.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Input Data
docs.text:
1. Ensure your PDB input is a dictionary {pdb_id: pdb_content}.
  2. Optionally, specify chains to design or amino acids to omit.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node Parameters
docs.text:
1. Select model version and adjust generation settings (e.g., batch size, temperature).
  2. Set reproducibility seed if needed.

docs.title: Sequence Design for Protein Backbones
docs.text:
• Generate diverse amino acid sequences for a given protein structure.
  • Restrict design to specific chains or omit certain amino acids.
  • Use batch mode for multiple structures.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example pdb Structures to run through the model. PDB {"A": "..."} ca_only Whether to parse CA-only structures and use CA-only models. BOOLEAN False model_name ProteinMPNN model name. COMBO v_48_020 use_soluble_model Whether to load weights trained on soluble proteins only. BOOLEAN False backbone_noise Std. dev. of Gaussian noise to add to backbone atoms. FLOAT 0.0 num_seq_per_target Number of sequences to generate per protein. INT 10 num_best_seq_per_target Number of top-scoring sequences to return. INT 1 batch_size Batch size. Reduce if running out of GPU memory. INT 1 max_length Max sequence length. INT 200000 sampling_temp Temperatures for amino acids (comma separated). STRING 0.1,0.2,0.3 omit_amino_acids Amino acids to omit (comma separated). STRING X chains_to_design Chains to design (comma separated, empty for all). STRING A,B seed Base seed value for randomness. INT 42 mode Mode to run the node in (MOCK, PROD, TEST). COMBO PROD

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example seqs.fasta All generated sequences. >A_seq_0\n... best_seqs.fasta Top best generated sequences. >A_best_seq_0\n...

docs.title: Sequence Generation
docs.text:
• Use higher sampling temperatures for more diverse sequences.
  • Adjust batch size based on available GPU memory.

docs.title: Model Selection
docs.text:
• Choose the model version and soluble weights according to your protein type.
  • For CA-only structures, ensure the model supports CA-only mode.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Error: CA-SolubleMPNN model is not available yet.: Set either ca_only or use_soluble_model to False.
  • Error: CA-v_48_030 model is not available yet.: Use a different model or set ca_only to False.
  • num_best_seq_per_target > num_seq_per_target: Ensure the number of best sequences does not exceed total generated.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• ProteinMPNN GitHub
  • Contact support for further assistance.

docs.title: Draw Mask
docs.text: Creates a custom mask by drawing on a canvas with adjustable size, brush, and grayscale color. Outputs a mask tensor for downstream processing.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Set canvas width and height.
  2. Adjust brush size and color as needed.
  3. Draw on the canvas to create your mask.
  4. Use the output mask in your workflow.

docs.title: 1. Configure Canvas
docs.text:
1. Choose desired width and height for the mask.
  2. Set brush size and color for drawing.

docs.title: 2. Draw and Export
docs.text:
1. Draw on the canvas using the configured brush.
  2. Export the mask for use in other nodes.

docs.title: Creating a Custom Mask
docs.text:
• Draw directly on the canvas to define mask regions.
  • Adjust brush size for fine or broad strokes.
  • Use grayscale brush color for mask intensity.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example canvas The base64-encoded canvas image to draw the mask on. CANVAS (UI-provided) width Width of the mask in pixels. INT 512 height Height of the mask in pixels. INT 512 brush_size Size of the drawing brush in pixels. INT 10 brush_color Grayscale color value for the brush (0=black, 255=white). INT 255

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example mask The generated mask tensor. (Tensor)

docs.title: Drawing Masks
docs.text:
• Use a larger brush for broad areas, smaller for details.
  • Set brush color to 255 for full mask, lower for partial transparency.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Combine with other masking nodes for complex effects.
  • Resize canvas to match target image dimensions for best results.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Mask appears empty: Ensure you have drawn on the canvas and brush color is not set to 0.
  • Output size mismatch: Set width and height to match your target image.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Refer to the platform documentation for node usage examples.
  • Visit the support forum for troubleshooting tips and community help.

docs.title: Dynamic Text
docs.text: Allows users to create dynamic text prompts with up to 10 variable string inputs, which can be referenced in the main text using placeholders (activated by clicking /). Useful for templates and workflows requiring flexible, user-driven text composition.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the Dynamic Text node to your workflow.
  2. Enter your main text, using input_1, input_2, etc. as placeholders.
  3. Fill in the values for each input field as needed.
  4. Use the output string in downstream nodes.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Drag the Dynamic Text node into your workflow editor.
  2. Connect it to other nodes as required.

docs.title: 2. Configure Inputs
docs.text:
1. In the text area, write your template using input_n placeholders. Placeholders can be added by clicking on / and selecting the required placeholder.
  2. Set values for each input field. Additional fields appear as you fill previous ones.

docs.title: Template Prompting
docs.text:
• Use for prompts that require user-supplied variables.
  • Supports up to 10 dynamic string inputs.
  • Placeholders are replaced with input values at runtime.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example text Main text with placeholders for variables STRING "Hello, {{input_1}}!"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example input_1 Value for {{input_1}} placeholder STRING "World" input_2 Value for {{input_2}} placeholder STRING "Alice" input_3 Value for {{input_3}} placeholder STRING "42" input_4 Value for {{input_4}} placeholder STRING "foo" input_5 Value for {{input_5}} placeholder STRING "bar" input_6 Value for {{input_6}} placeholder STRING "baz" input_7 Value for {{input_7}} placeholder STRING "qux" input_8 Value for {{input_8}} placeholder STRING "quux" input_9 Value for {{input_9}} placeholder STRING "corge" input_10 Value for {{input_10}} placeholder STRING "grault"

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example text Final string with variables replaced "Hello, World!"

docs.title: Template Design
docs.text: • Keep templates concise for easier maintenance.

docs.title: Input Management
docs.text:
• Only fill as many input fields as needed; unused placeholders remain unchanged.
  • Use default values for common cases to speed up workflow setup.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Placeholders misaplaced: Ensure the match between input_n placeholder and actual input.
  • Unexpected output: Check for typos in placeholder names and input values.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Review node configuration and input values.
  • Check workflow logs for error messages.

docs.title: File
docs.text: Provides access to files uploaded to the workflow, returning both the file path and its UTF-8 contents (if text). Useful for integrating file data into node pipelines.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Upload a file to the workflow input directory.
  2. Add the File node to your workflow.
  3. Select the desired file from the dropdown.

docs.title: 1. Upload Files
docs.text:
1. Place files in the workflow's input directory.
  2. Ensure files are accessible and have appropriate permissions.

docs.title: 2. Add and Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Insert the File node into your workflow.
  2. Select a file from the provided list.

docs.title: Reading File Path and Contents
docs.text:
• Select a file to output its path and, if text, its contents.
  • Use the file path output for downstream nodes that require file references.
  • Use the text contents output for nodes that process text data.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example file File to load from the input directory string (filename) "example.txt"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example file_path Path to the selected file "/inputs/example.txt" text_contents UTF-8 contents of the file (empty for non-text files) "Hello, world!"

docs.title: File Management
docs.text:
• Keep the input directory organized for easier file selection.
  • Use descriptive filenames to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Data Handling
docs.text:
• Only use the text_contents output for supported text file types.
  • For binary or unsupported files, rely on the file_path output.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• File not listed: Ensure the file is in the correct input directory and has proper permissions.
  • Empty text output: The file may be binary or an unsupported format.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check workflow logs for error messages.
  • Verify file accessibility and format.

docs.title: Image
docs.text: A node that lets you select images from your input directory or upload new ones directly. Provides instant preview and handles various image formats.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add Image Input node to your workflow
  2. Either:
  3. Select an existing image from the dropdown
  4. Click "Choose file to upload" for a new image
  5. Check the preview to confirm your selection
  6. Connect to image processing nodes

docs.title: Select Existing Image
docs.text:
• Choose from files in your input directory
  • Preview updates automatically
  • Supports common image formats

docs.title: Upload New Image
docs.text:
• Click upload or drag & drop
  • File is copied to input directory
  • Available for future use

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example Image Image file selection File Select/Upload photo.jpg

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example IMAGE RGB image tensor torch.Tensor [1, H, W, 3] MASK Alpha channel mask torch.Tensor [1, H, W]

docs.title: File Management
docs.text:
• Use descriptive filenames
  • Clean up unused images
  • Keep input directory organized

docs.title: Image Selection
docs.text:
• Check preview before proceeding
  • Verify image dimensions
  • Consider workflow requirements

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No Files Listed: Add images to input directory
  • Upload Failed: Check file format and size
  • Preview Not Loading: Verify image isn't corrupted

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check supported image formats
  • Verify input directory permissions
  • Review image requirements documentation

docs.title: Text
docs.text: A simple node that lets you add and edit text content in your workflow. Perfect for prompts, configuration, or any text-based input.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add Text Input node to your workflow
  2. Click the text field to start typing
  3. Enter your desired text content
  4. Connect to nodes that process text

docs.title: Single Line Text
docs.text:
• Type directly into the field
  • Press Enter to confirm
  • Great for simple prompts or commands

docs.title: Multi-Line Text
docs.text:
• Click and drag field corner to expand
  • Support for multiple paragraphs
  • Useful for longer content or formatting

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example Text Your text content String Hello world!

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example TEXT Entered text content Your input text

docs.title: Content Entry
docs.text:
• Be clear and concise
  • Check spelling and formatting
  • Consider downstream node requirements

docs.title: Text Formatting
docs.text:
• Use appropriate line breaks
  • Keep formatting consistent
  • Consider character limits

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty Output: Default blank text will be used
  • Formatting Lost: Check for unsupported characters
  • Connection Error: Verify receiving node accepts text

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Review text formatting guidelines
  • Check node connection compatibility
  • Consult workflow examples

docs.title: LLM Nodes
docs.text: LLM (Large Language Model) nodes allow you to interact with various AI models directly in your workflows. Each LLM provider (Anthropic, OpenAI, Google, etc.) has its own node with consistent interfaces but unique model options.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Input Field Description Configuration Details Model Select which model version to use • Options vary by provider• More powerful models for analysis/creation• Basic models for simple tasks• Example: Claude 3.5 Sonnet (Anthropic) System Prompt Instructions that control how the AI responds • Multiline text field• Sets formatting, style, and tone• Default: "Respond directly to the user's message. Be concise." Prompt Main input field for your request • Supports dynamic input references• Press "/" to access available inputs• Can reference knowledge base content Temperature Controls response creativity • Range: 0.0 to 1.0 (slider)• Default: 0.5• Lower = more focused• Higher = more creative Max Tokens Controls maximum response length • Range: 0 to 4096 (slider)• Default: 1024 (~750 words)• Adjust based on needed length

docs.title: Optional Context Inputs
docs.text: Input Purpose Use Cases Input 1 Primary context slot • Main knowledge base• Primary reference material Input 2 Secondary context slot • Supporting information• Additional context Input 3 Tertiary context slot • Supplementary data• Extra references Input 4 Quaternary context slot • Final context layer• Additional materials

docs.title: Context Input Features
docs.text:
• Connect to knowledge bases
  • Pass in reference materials
  • Include additional context
  • Chain outputs from other nodes

docs.title: Input Reference Syntax
docs.text: Step Action Details 1 Trigger Menu Type "/" in prompt field 2 Select Input Choose from input_1 through input_4 3 Reference Format Appears as {{input_1}} in prompt 4 Runtime Behavior References replaced with actual values

docs.title: Example Prompt
docs.text:
Context: {{input_1}}
Based on the above context, please summarize the main points.

docs.title: Output Specifications
docs.text: Output Type Description Usage Output STRING AI model's response • Contains generated text• Format based on prompts• Can connect to other nodes

docs.title: Model Selection
docs.text: Consideration Recommendation Complex Tasks Use stronger models Simple Tasks Choose basic models Cost Efficiency Consider performance tradeoffs

docs.title: System Prompts
docs.text: Aspect Guidance Format Be specific about desired output Tone Set clear expectations Rules Include consistent instructions

docs.title: Context Management
docs.text: Practice Implementation Knowledge Bases Connect relevant sources Input Priority Order by importance Dynamic References Use appropriately

docs.title: Response Configuration
docs.text: Setting Guidelines Max Tokens Set based on needs Context Limits Consider model constraints Buffer Allow for longer responses

docs.title: Output
docs.text: View and save results from your workflow. The Output node automatically formats and displays your data in a readable way.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add Output node to your workflow
  2. Connect any node's output to it
  3. Run your workflow
  4. View results in:
  5. Node preview (toggle raw/formatted views)
  6. Workflow Runs panel on the right (shows history)

docs.title: Preview Mode
docs.text:
• Shows formatted content (like rendered Markdown)
  • Great for reviewing reports and text
  • Automatically detects and displays images

docs.title: Raw Mode
docs.text:
• Shows underlying data structure
  • Useful for debugging
  • Displays exact values being passed

docs.title: Saving Ouptuts
docs.text:
• All outputs are viewable in the Workflow Runs panel
  • Each run shows timestamp and duration
  • Access historical results anytime

docs.title: Workflow Organization
docs.text:
• Add Output nodes to inspect intermediate results
  • Use multiple outputs to compare different stages
  • Label outputs clearly for better workflow readability

docs.title: Viewing Results
docs.text:
• Use preview mode for formatted content
  • Switch to raw mode to verify data structure
  • Check Workflow Runs panel for previous results

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Empty Output: Check input connection
  • Preview Not Loading: Try switching to raw view
  • Unexpected Format: Verify input data type

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Verify node connections
  • Check Workflow Runs history
  • Try both preview and raw modes

docs.title: Notion Writer
docs.text: Create and update pages in Notion databases and workspaces through the Notion API.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Create a Notion Integration
  2. Copy your Integration Token
  3. Share your database/page with the integration
  4. Add the Notion Writer node to your workflow
  5. Paste your token and database ID

docs.title: 1. Create a Notion Integration
docs.text:
1. Go to Notion Integrations page
  2. Click "New integration"
  3. Name your integration
  4. Select the workspace where you'll use it
  5. Set capabilities (needs Content Capabilities)

docs.title: 2. Configure Permissions
docs.text:
1. Copy your "Internal Integration Token"
  2. Go to the Notion page/database you want to write to
  3. Click "•••" → "Add connections"
  4. Find and select your integration

docs.title: 3. Get Parent ID
docs.text:
1. Open your target database/page in browser
  2. Copy the ID from the URL:
  3. Database: https://notion.so/workspace/[DATABASE_ID]?v=...
  4. Page: https://notion.so/workspace/[PAGE_ID]

docs.title: Create Page in Database
docs.text:
{
  "parent_type": "database",
  "parent_id": "8a5c9e1b2d3f4g5h6i7j8k9l",
  "title": "Meeting Notes",
  "content": "# Team Meeting\n\n## Agenda\n- Project updates\n- Next steps"
}

docs.title: Create Subpage
docs.text:
{
  "parent_type": "page",
  "parent_id": "1a2b3c4d5e6f7g8h9i0j",
  "title": "Project Documentation",
  "content": "# Overview\n\nThis document covers..."
}

docs.title: Page with Cover Image
docs.text:
{
  "parent_type": "database",
  "parent_id": "8a5c9e1b2d3f4g5h6i7j8k9l",
  "title": "Product Launch",
  "content": "# Launch Plan\n\n## Timeline...",
  "cover_url": "https://example.com/launch-banner.jpg"
}

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example Token Notion Integration Token Password secret_abc123... Parent Type Where to create content Select database or page Parent ID Target database/page ID String 8a5c9e1b2d3f... Title Page title String Meeting Notes Content Markdown content Text # Heading\n\nContent...

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example Cover URL Page cover image String https://example.com/image.jpg

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example Status Operation result Success or Error Response API response with URL {"url": "https://notion.so/..."}

docs.title: Content Structure
docs.text:
• Use markdown for formatting
  • Include clear headings
  • Structure content hierarchically

docs.title: Organization
docs.text:
• Use consistent naming
  • Leverage database properties
  • Keep page structures consistent

docs.title: Performance & Security
docs.text:
• Store tokens securely
  • Verify integration permissions
  • Monitor API rate limits

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Access Denied: Check integration permissions
  • Invalid Token: Verify token is correct
  • Parent Not Found: Confirm ID and sharing settings

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Test markdown in Notion's Web App
  • Check Notion API Status
  • Review Notion API Documentation

docs.title: Slack Writer
docs.text: Send messages to Slack channels and users through the Slack API.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Create a Slack App and install it to your workspace
  2. Copy your Bot User OAuth Token (starts with xoxb-)
  3. Add the Slack Writer node to your workflow
  4. Paste your token and specify a channel (e.g., #general)
  5. Send a test message

docs.title: 1. Create a Slack App
docs.text:
1. Go to Slack API Apps page
  2. Click "Create New App" → "From scratch"
  3. Name your app and select your workspace

docs.title: 2. Configure Bot Permissions
docs.text:
1. Navigate to "OAuth & Permissions"
  2. Add these Bot Token Scopes:
  3. chat:write - Send messages
  4. chat:write.customize - Customize bot name/icon
  5. channels:read - View channels
  6. groups:read - View private channels

docs.title: 3. Install & Configure
docs.text:
1. Click "Install to Workspace" and authorize
  2. Copy the "Bot User OAuth Token"
  3. In Slack, invite bot to channels with /invite @YourBotName

docs.title: Simple Message
docs.text:
{
  "channel": "#general",
  "message": "Hello team! Important meeting at 2 PM."
}

docs.title: Thread Reply
docs.text:
{
  "channel": "#general",
  "message": "Here are the meeting notes.",
  "thread_timestamp": "1680123456.789000"
}

docs.title: Rich Message with Block Kit
docs.text:
[
  {
    "type": "header",
    "text": {
      "type": "plain_text",
      "text": "🚨 System Alert",
      "emoji": true
    }
  },
  {
    "type": "section",
    "text": {
      "type": "mrkdwn",
      "text": "*Database Backup Complete*\nAll systems operating normally."
    }
  }
]

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example Slack Token Bot User OAuth Token Password xoxb-1234567890-abcdefg-hijklmnop Channel Channel or user to message String #general or @username Message Text content (if not using Block Kit) String Hello team!

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example Block Kit JSON Rich message formatting JSON See examples below Icon Emoji Bot icon emoji String :robot: Icon URL Bot icon image URL String https://example.com/icon.png Thread Timestamp Reply to thread String 1680123456.789000

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example Status API call status ok Thread Timestamp Message timestamp 1680123456.789000 Response Full API response See below

docs.title: Message Design
docs.text:
• Keep messages concise and well-structured
  • Use Block Kit for complex layouts
  • Include clear call-to-actions

docs.title: Threading
docs.text:
• Use threads to organize conversations
  • Save timestamps for follow-ups
  • Avoid deep nesting

docs.title: Performance & Security
docs.text:
• Store tokens securely
  • Batch messages when possible
  • Monitor rate limits

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Message Not Sent: Check token and channel permissions
  • Invalid Token: Ensure token starts with xoxb-
  • Channel Not Found: Verify channel exists and bot is invited

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Validate Block Kit JSON in Block Kit Builder
  • Check Slack API Status
  • Review Slack's API Documentation

docs.title: Edit Object
docs.text: Edit specific objects in an image using search-and-edit operations, allowing targeted modifications based on prompts and masks.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your input image and mask.
  2. Specify the object to edit using the search prompt.
  3. Set the edit mode (e.g., replace, remove).
  4. Adjust grow mask if needed.
  5. Run the node to apply the edit.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Obtain or create an image and a corresponding mask highlighting the object to edit.
  2. Define the search prompt describing the object.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Select the desired edit mode (e.g., replace, remove).
  2. Optionally adjust the grow mask value for mask expansion.

docs.title: Replace an Object
docs.text:
• Use a search prompt to identify the object.
  • Set edit mode to "replace" and provide a new prompt for the replacement.

docs.title: Remove an Object
docs.text:
• Use a search prompt to identify the object.
  • Set edit mode to "remove" to erase the object from the image.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Input image tensor image_tensor mask Mask highlighting the object to edit tensor mask_tensor edit_mode Edit operation mode (replace, remove, etc.) string replace search_prompt Description of the object to edit string "red apple" grow_mask Pixels to expand the mask int 3 seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example prompt Prompt for the new object/content string "green apple" negative_prompt Negative prompt to avoid unwanted content string "no leaves"

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Edited image tensor edited_image_tensor

docs.title: Prompt Engineering
docs.text:
• Use clear, specific search prompts to accurately target objects.
  • Combine search and edit prompts for precise control.

docs.title: Mask Preparation
docs.text:
• Ensure the mask closely matches the object boundaries.
  • Use grow_mask to slightly expand the mask if edges are missed.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Object not detected: Refine the search prompt or improve the mask accuracy.
  • Unwanted areas edited: Adjust the mask or reduce grow_mask value.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check input image and mask alignment.
  • Review prompt wording for clarity.
  • Consult platform documentation for further guidance.

docs.title: Erase
docs.text: Removes selected regions from an input image using a mask, producing a clean background in the erased area.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your input image and a mask highlighting the area to erase.
  2. Run the node to generate an image with the masked region erased.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Obtain or create the image you want to edit.
  2. Create a mask image where the area to erase is marked.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Upload the image and mask.
  2. Set the batch size and seed as needed.

docs.title: Erasing Unwanted Objects
docs.text:
• Use a mask to select unwanted objects or regions.
  • The node will erase the masked area, filling it with a clean background.
  • Useful for removing text, people, or artifacts from images.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Input image to process image (uploaded file) mask Mask image for erase region image (uploaded file) seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Image with region erased (output image)

docs.title: Mask Preparation
docs.text:
• Use a precise mask to target only the area you want to erase.
  • Avoid overly large masks for best results.

docs.title: Image Quality
docs.text:
• Use high-resolution images for cleaner erasure.
  • Adjust the seed for different output variations.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Output is not as expected: Check that the mask accurately covers the area to erase and that the input image is clear.
  • Node fails to run: Ensure all required fields are filled and the image/mask sizes are supported.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Consult the platform documentation for node usage tips.
  • Check community forums for similar issues and solutions.

docs.title: Inpaint
docs.text: Inpaints masked regions of an input image using Stable Diffusion, guided by a text prompt and optional mask growth.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare an input image and a mask indicating regions to inpaint.
  2. Enter a descriptive prompt for the desired inpainted content.
  3. (Optional) Adjust the grow mask value to expand the masked area.
  4. Run the node to generate the inpainted image.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Inputs
docs.text:
1. Obtain or create an image to edit.
  2. Create a mask image where white areas indicate regions to inpaint.
  3. Write a prompt describing the desired result.

docs.title: 2. Configure Node
docs.text:
1. Set the required fields: image, mask, and prompt.
  2. Optionally adjust grow mask, seed, and batch size.

docs.title: 3. Run and Review
docs.text:
1. Execute the node.
  2. Review the output image and adjust parameters as needed.

docs.title: Inpainting an Object
docs.text:
• Remove unwanted objects by masking them and describing the background in the prompt.
  • Restore damaged or missing parts of an image.
  • Change specific regions by masking and prompting for new content.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Input image to inpaint tensor/image (image tensor) mask Mask image (white = inpaint region) tensor/image (mask tensor) prompt Text prompt guiding inpainting string "A vase of flowers"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example grow_mask Expand mask region by N pixels (max 100) int 10 negative_prompt Text prompt to avoid inpainting features string "blurry, distorted" seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Inpainted output image (image tensor)

docs.title: Prompt Engineering
docs.text:
• Use clear, descriptive prompts for best results.
  • Specify undesired features in the negative prompt.

docs.title: Mask Preparation
docs.text:
• Use precise masks for targeted inpainting.
  • Adjust grow mask to ensure full coverage of the region.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Output is not as expected: Refine the prompt or mask for better results.
  • Masked area not fully inpainted: Increase the grow mask value.
  • Node fails with input error: Ensure all required fields are set and valid.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check documentation for input formatting.
  • Review example configurations for guidance.

docs.title: Outpaint
docs.text: Expands an image beyond its original borders using Stable Diffusion, generating new content that blends seamlessly with the existing image.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Upload or select an input image.
  2. Specify the number of pixels to expand in each direction (left, right, up, down).
  3. Enter a prompt to guide the outpainting.
  4. (Optional) Set a random seed and batch size.
  5. Run the node to generate the expanded image.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Your Image
docs.text:
1. Ensure your image is at least 64x64 pixels.
  2. Choose an image with content you want to expand.

docs.title: 2. Configure Outpainting
docs.text:
1. Set the number of pixels to expand for each side (left, right, up, down).
  2. Provide a descriptive prompt for the new content.
  3. Adjust creativity and seed as needed for variation.

docs.title: Expanding a Landscape Photo
docs.text:
• Expand a landscape image to create a wider scene.
  • Use prompts like "mountains in the distance" or "sunset sky" for natural transitions.

docs.title: Creating Extended Portraits
docs.text:
• Add space above or beside a portrait for creative compositions.
  • Guide the expansion with prompts such as "soft background" or "studio lighting".

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Input image to expand tensor (image tensor) prompt Text prompt guiding the outpainting string "forest at dusk" left Pixels to expand on the left int 128 right Pixels to expand on the right int 128 up Pixels to expand at the top int 64 down Pixels to expand at the bottom int 64

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example creativity Controls randomness/variation float 0.7 seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Outpainted image tensor(s) (image tensor)

docs.title: Prompt Engineering
docs.text:
• Use clear, descriptive prompts for best results.
  • Match the prompt style to the original image content.

docs.title: Image Preparation
docs.text:
• Start with high-quality, uncluttered images.
  • Avoid expanding images with complex, detailed edges for smoother transitions.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Output looks unnatural: Refine your prompt or reduce the number of pixels expanded.
  • Node fails with input error: Ensure all required fields are filled and at least one expansion direction is non-zero.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check the platform documentation for node usage examples.
  • Review input requirements and try different prompt variations.

docs.title: Remove Background
docs.text: Removes the background from an input image, isolating the main subject for further processing or export.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Prepare your input image.
  2. Select the Remove Background node in your workflow.
  3. Connect your image input and run the node to obtain a background-free result.

docs.title: 1. Add the Node
docs.text:
1. Open your node editor.
  2. Locate and add the "Remove Background" node to your workspace.

docs.title: 2. Connect Inputs
docs.text:
1. Connect your image input to the node.
  2. Configure required parameters as needed.

docs.title: 3. Run the Node
docs.text: 1. Execute the workflow to process the image and remove its background.

docs.title: Isolate Subject from Image
docs.text:
• Use to extract the main subject from a photo for compositing or editing.
  • Ideal for preparing images for presentations, design, or further AI processing.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Input image tensor torch.Tensor (image tensor) mask Optional mask to guide removal torch.Tensor (mask tensor) batch_size Number of images to process int 1

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Image with background removed (image tensor)

docs.title: Image Preparation
docs.text:
• Use high-quality images for best results.
  • Ensure the subject is clearly distinguishable from the background.

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• Combine with other nodes for advanced editing.
  • Batch process multiple images for efficiency.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Output is not as expected: Check that the input image is clear and the subject is distinct from the background.
  • Processing fails for large images: Ensure the image does not exceed the maximum supported size (4,194,304 pixels).

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Consult platform documentation for node usage guidance.
  • Verify input formats and node connections in your workflow.

docs.title: Stable Diffusion - Advanced
docs.text: Generates high-quality images from text prompts using advanced Stable Diffusion 3.0/3.5 models, supporting custom prompts, negative prompts, aspect ratios, and more.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Select the "Stable Diffusion - Advanced" node in your workflow.
  2. Enter your desired prompt and negative prompt.
  3. Configure aspect ratio, seed, batch size, style preset, and other parameters as needed.
  4. Run the node to generate images.

docs.title: 1. Node Placement
docs.text:
1. Add the node to your workspace from the node library.
  2. Connect required inputs (prompt, aspect ratio, etc.).

docs.title: 2. Parameter Configuration
docs.text:
1. Adjust parameters for your use case (e.g., batch size, seed).
  2. Optionally set a style preset for stylistic control.

docs.title: Text-to-Image Generation
docs.text:
• Generate images from descriptive text prompts.
  • Use negative prompts to avoid unwanted elements.
  • Adjust aspect ratio and batch size for output customization.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example prompt Text describing the desired image string "A sunset beach" negative_prompt Text describing what to avoid in the image string "blurry, dark" aspect_ratio Output image aspect ratio (e.g., 1:1, 16:9) string "1:1" seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1 style_preset Style preset for image generation string "photographic"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example images Generated images as tensors [Tensor]

docs.title: Prompt Engineering
docs.text:
• Use clear, descriptive prompts for best results.
  • Specify negative prompts to filter out unwanted features.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Adjust batch size and seed for reproducibility and variety.
  • Experiment with style presets for different artistic effects.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Images not as expected: Refine your prompt and negative prompt for clarity.
  • Output size incorrect: Check aspect ratio and batch size settings.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Consult the platform documentation for node usage examples.
  • Verify your input values and try different parameters for improved results.

docs.title: Stable Diffusion - Control
docs.text: A node for applying advanced control techniques (e.g., ControlNet, style transfer) to Stable Diffusion image generation, allowing precise guidance using an input image and control type.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Connect your input image and specify the control type (e.g., style, pose).
  2. Set the prompt and negative prompt for image generation.
  3. Adjust control strength and other parameters as needed.
  4. Run the node to generate controlled outputs.

docs.title: 1. Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Ensure Stable Diffusion and required control models are installed in your environment.
  2. Prepare an input image for guidance.

docs.title: 2. Node Configuration
docs.text:
1. Select the control type (e.g., style, pose).
  2. Fill in prompts and adjust parameters for your use case.

docs.title: Style Transfer
docs.text:
• Use an input image and set control type to "style" for style-guided generation.
  • Adjust control strength to balance fidelity and creativity.

docs.title: Pose or Other Controls
docs.text:
• Set control type to "pose" or other supported types for pose-guided or custom control.
  • The output will follow the structure of the input image.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Input image for control guidance tensor [image tensor] control_type Type of control (e.g., style, pose) string style prompt Text prompt for image generation string "A sunny beach" negative_prompt Negative prompt to avoid unwanted features string "blurry, dark" aspect_ratio Desired aspect ratio (for style only) string "16:9" seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1 control_strength Degree of control influence (0-1) float 0.7

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Generated image(s) as tensor [image tensor]

docs.title: Control Type Selection
docs.text:
• Choose the control type that matches your guidance image (e.g., use "style" for style transfer).
  • For non-style controls, aspect ratio is ignored and the output matches the input image resolution.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Adjust control strength for desired balance between guidance and creativity.
  • Use consistent seeds for reproducible results.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Output not matching guidance image: Ensure the control type matches the input image's content and use an appropriate control strength.
  • Aspect ratio ignored: For non-style controls, aspect ratio is not applied; output will match input image resolution.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check your model installation and input formats.
  • Review logs for warnings about parameter usage.

docs.title: Stable Diffusion - Core
docs.text: Generates images from text prompts using the Stable Diffusion Core model, supporting basic prompt-to-image workflows with essential configuration options.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Select the Stable Diffusion - Core node in your workflow.
  2. Provide a text prompt and adjust required settings.
  3. Run the node to generate images.

docs.title: 1. Add the Node
docs.text:
1. Open your node editor.
  2. Drag the Stable Diffusion - Core node into your workspace.

docs.title: 2. Configure Inputs
docs.text:
1. Enter your desired prompt and negative prompt.
  2. Set aspect ratio, style, seed, batch size, and image strength as needed.

docs.title: 3. Generate Images
docs.text:
1. Connect the node and execute the workflow.
  2. Retrieve generated images from the node output.

docs.title: Text-to-Image Generation
docs.text:
• Input a descriptive prompt to generate an image.
  • Adjust style, aspect ratio, and batch size for different outputs.
  • Use negative prompts to avoid unwanted elements.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example model Model identifier for generation string "sd-core" aspect_ratio Output image aspect ratio string "1:1" prompt Main text prompt for image generation string "A sunset" negative_prompt Text to avoid in the image string "blurry" style_preset Style preset for the image string "photographic" seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 1 image_strength Strength of image guidance (0-1) float 0.5 cfg_scale Classifier-free guidance scale float 7.5

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Generated image tensor

docs.title: Prompt Engineering
docs.text:
• Use clear, descriptive prompts for best results.
  • Experiment with style presets to achieve different visual effects.

docs.title: Performance & Quality
docs.text:
• Adjust batch size for faster or bulk generation.
  • Set a fixed seed for reproducible outputs.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Images not as expected: Refine your prompt or adjust style/negative prompts.
  • Generation fails: Ensure all required fields are filled and valid.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check the node documentation for configuration examples.
  • Review logs for error messages during generation.

docs.title: Stable Diffusion - Ultra
docs.text: A high-quality text-to-image node for generating images from prompts using the Stable Diffusion Ultra model, supporting advanced control over image size and batch generation.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Select the Stable Diffusion - Ultra node in your workflow.
  2. Provide a prompt describing the desired image.
  3. Set the aspect ratio, seed, batch size, and other parameters as needed.
  4. Run the node to generate images.

docs.title: 1. Node Placement
docs.text:
1. Add the Stable Diffusion - Ultra node to your workspace.
  2. Connect required input nodes (e.g., prompt source).

docs.title: 2. Parameter Configuration
docs.text:
1. Adjust aspect ratio, seed, and batch size for your use case.
  2. Optionally, provide a negative prompt or image for image-to-image mode.

docs.title: Text-to-Image Generation
docs.text:
• Generate high-quality images from text prompts.
  • Control image size and batch output.

docs.title: Image-to-Image Mode
docs.text:
• Use an input image as guidance for generation.
  • Adjust image strength for blending.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example prompt Text prompt describing the image to create string "A sunset..." aspect_ratio Desired aspect ratio (e.g., "1:1", "16:9") string "1:1" seed Random seed for reproducibility int 42 batch_size Number of images to generate int 4

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example negative_prompt Text to avoid in the generated image string "blurry" image Input image for image-to-image mode tensor/image (image tensor) image_strength Strength of guidance from input image (0-1) float 0.5

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Generated image(s) as tensor (image tensor)

docs.title: Prompt Engineering
docs.text:
• Use clear, descriptive prompts for best results.
  • Experiment with different aspect ratios for varied outputs.

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Use lower batch sizes for faster results.
  • Adjust image strength for optimal image-to-image blending.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Images not as expected: Refine your prompt or adjust aspect ratio.
  • Slow generation: Reduce batch size or image resolution.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check the node documentation for parameter details.
  • Review workflow connections and input values.

docs.title: Upscale Advanced
docs.text: Enhances image resolution using advanced upscaling algorithms with support for large images and custom aspect ratios.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the Upscale Advanced node to your workflow.
  2. Connect an input image.
  3. Configure optional parameters as needed.
  4. Run the workflow to obtain an upscaled image.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open your node editor.
  2. Locate and add the "Upscale Advanced" node from the node library.

docs.title: 2. Connect and Configure
docs.text:
1. Connect an image input.
  2. Adjust parameters (e.g., aspect ratio, seed, creativity) as needed.
  3. Execute the workflow.

docs.title: High-Quality Image Upscaling
docs.text:
• Upscale images up to 9MP (max 9437184 pixels).
  • Supports aspect ratios from 0.4 to 2.5.
  • Customizable creativity and seed for varied results.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image Image to upscale Tensor image_tensor

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example prompt Text prompt for guidance String "A detailed landscape" negative_prompt Text prompt to avoid certain features String "blurry, low quality" seed Random seed for reproducibility Integer 42 batch_size Number of images to process in batch Integer 1 creativity Controls variation (0.2–0.5, default 0.35) Float 0.35

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image Upscaled image tensor image_tensor

docs.title: Image Preparation
docs.text:
• Use high-quality input images for best results.
  • Ensure input image size is between 64px and 9MP.

docs.title: Parameter Tuning
docs.text:
• Adjust creativity for more or less variation.
  • Set a fixed seed for reproducible outputs.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Input image too small or too large: Ensure image size is between 64px and 9MP.
  • Aspect ratio out of range: Use aspect ratios between 0.4 and 2.5.
  • Timeouts on large images: For very large images, allow extra processing time (default timeout is 180s).

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check node documentation and verify input parameters.
  • For persistent issues, consult your platform's support resources.

docs.title: Upscale Fast
docs.text: Quickly upscale images with minimal configuration, optimized for speed and efficiency.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the Upscale Fast node to your workflow.
  2. Connect an input image.
  3. Run the node to receive an upscaled output.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open your node editor.
  2. Locate and add the "Upscale Fast" node.

docs.title: 2. Connect Inputs
docs.text:
1. Connect the image you want to upscale to the node's input.
  2. Adjust configuration as needed.

docs.title: 3. Run and Retrieve Output
docs.text:
1. Execute the workflow.
  2. Retrieve the upscaled image from the node's output.

docs.title: Single Image Upscaling
docs.text:
• Use for fast upscaling of a single image.
  • Minimal configuration required.

docs.title: Batch Upscaling
docs.text: • Process multiple images by adjusting the batch size input.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example image The image to upscale tensor input_image

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example image The upscaled image tensor upscaled_image

docs.title: Image Preparation
docs.text:
• Use high-quality input images for best results.
  • Ensure input image size is within supported range (32–1536 px per side).

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• For large batches, monitor memory usage.
  • Use this node for speed; for higher quality, consider advanced upscaling nodes.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Input image too small or too large: Ensure image dimensions are between 32 and 1536 pixels per side.
  • Output not as expected: Check input image quality and try different images.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Consult the platform documentation for node usage guidance.
  • Check community forums for workflow examples and troubleshooting tips.

docs.title: Inspect
docs.text: Node for inspecting and logging data flowing through the workflow. Displays a visual preview and logs information about the input value.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the Inspect node to your workflow.
  2. Connect any node output to the Inspect node's input.
  3. Run the workflow to view inspection results and image preview.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Locate the Inspect node.
  2. Drag it into your workflow editor.

docs.title: 2. Connect and Configure
docs.text:
1. Connect the output you want to inspect to the Inspect node's input.
  2. Optionally, toggle logging with the write_logs input.

docs.title: Inspecting Data
docs.text:
• Use to debug or visualize any data flowing through your workflow.
  • Supports tensors, images, JSON, and strings.
  • Preview images are auto-extracted if possible.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example value The value to inspect Any 42, "text", tensor write_logs Enable/disable logging Boolean True

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example value Inspected value (as string/JSON) "42", "{...}" image_preview Preview image tensor tensor

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
• Use Inspect nodes at key workflow points to monitor data.
  • Enable write_logs for detailed logging during development.

docs.title: Visualization
docs.text:
• Use the image preview to quickly verify image data.
  • Chain multiple Inspect nodes for stepwise inspection.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No image preview: Input data may not be an image or valid base64 string.
  • Unreadable output: Non-JSON or complex objects may be stringified.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Check workflow logs for error messages.
  • Review input data types for compatibility.

docs.title: Regex Search and Match
docs.text: Performs a regular expression search on input text and returns all matches as a list.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the Regex Search and Match node to your workflow.
  2. Enter the text to search in the "text_input" field.
  3. Provide a valid regular expression in the "regex_pattern" field.
  4. Run the node to retrieve all matches.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open your node editor.
  2. Drag the Regex Search and Match node into your workspace.

docs.title: 2. Configure Inputs
docs.text:
1. Enter the text you want to search.
  2. Specify the regex pattern for matching.

docs.title: Extracting Words
docs.text:
• Find all words matching a specific pattern (e.g., all 6-letter words).
  • Use for text analysis, validation, or extraction tasks.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example text_input The input text to search for matches STRING "Find all words here" regex_pattern Regular expression pattern to match STRING "\b[a-zA-Z]{6}\b"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example matches List of all regex matches found ["search", "result"]

docs.title: Regex Construction
docs.text:
• Test your regex patterns before use.
  • Use raw strings (prefix with r) to avoid escape issues.

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Use specific patterns to avoid excessive backtracking.
  • Limit input size for large-scale searches.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No matches found: Check your regex pattern and input text for correctness.
  • Invalid regex error: Ensure your pattern is valid and properly escaped.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text: • Refer to Python's re module documentation for regex syntax and examples.

docs.title: Regex Search and Replace
docs.text: Performs regex-based search and replace on input text, or extracts all matches using a regular expression pattern.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Add the Regex Search and Replace node to your workflow.
  2. Enter the input text and regex pattern.
  3. Specify replacement text (for replace) or leave blank (for match).
  4. Run the node to get replaced text or a list of matches.

docs.title: 1. Add Node to Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open your node editor.
  2. Drag the Regex Search and Replace node into your workspace.

docs.title: 2. Configure Inputs
docs.text:
1. Enter the text to process.
  2. Provide a valid regex pattern.
  3. (For replace) Enter the replacement text.

docs.title: Find and Replace
docs.text:
• Replace all matches of a regex pattern in a string.
  • Example: Replace all 5-letter words with "#####".

docs.title: Find Matches
docs.text:
• Extract all substrings matching a regex pattern.
  • Example: Find all 6-letter words in a paragraph.

docs.title: Required Inputs
docs.text: Field Description Type Example text_input The input text to process STRING "Hello world" regex_pattern Regular expression pattern to match STRING "\b\w{5}\b" replacement_text Text to replace each match (replace only) STRING "#####"

docs.title: Optional Inputs
docs.text: None

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: Field Description Example replaced_text Text after replacements (replace node) "##### world" matches List of all matches (match node) ["sample", "string"]

docs.title: Regex Patterns
docs.text:
• Test your regex pattern before use.
  • Use raw strings (prefix with r) to avoid escape issues.

docs.title: Usage Tips
docs.text:
• For complex replacements, verify the output with sample data.
  • Use specific patterns to avoid unintended matches.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No matches found: Check your regex pattern for accuracy.
  • Unexpected replacements: Ensure the pattern does not match unintended text.

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
• Refer to Python's re module documentation for regex syntax.
  • Use online regex testers to validate your patterns.
